[Van der Kloot]: Is that good?

[Van der Kloot]: I live at 146 Pine Ridge Road.

[Van der Kloot]: Good evening, members of the City Council Governance Committee, Chair Tseng, fellow members of the Charter Review Committee, and Medford community members.

[Van der Kloot]: As you know, I served on the school committee for 32 years.

[Van der Kloot]: I asked to be appointed to the Charter Review Committee when I realized there was no one with school committee experience on the Charter Review Committee.

[Van der Kloot]: While some of my former school committee colleagues may not agree with what we have put forth in the draft,

[Van der Kloot]: that you are reviewing tonight, rest assured that it has been put forth with deep reflection, not only my own, but with the very diligent subcommittee and the entire Charter Review Committee.

[Van der Kloot]: As someone who served with three different mayors, I strongly advocated for the mayor, whoever it might be, to remain as the school committee chair because the advantages are so strong.

[Van der Kloot]: As a school committee member, I had access to the mayor at every meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: Not just me, every school committee member had the advantage of being able to discuss key educational issues in front of the mayor.

[Van der Kloot]: being present at the school committee meetings ensures that the mayor is familiar with all the issues in detail and has buy-in.

[Van der Kloot]: Our charter subcommittee interviewed all three mayors and each underscored how important it has been or is for them to fully comprehend school committee issues, our school issues, especially given the significant percentage of the budget which is spent on education.

[Van der Kloot]: I remember the frustration of my colleagues across the aisle, that is you, the city council members, in former years when mayors did not come before them.

[Van der Kloot]: You never heard that from school committee members.

[Van der Kloot]: We worked closely with the mayors and they had buy-in.

[Van der Kloot]: To my former colleagues eager to do away with the role of the mayor as the chair of the school committee, I can only say be careful what you ask for.

[Van der Kloot]: School committee members play a very vital role in supporting all students and education, and that is enhanced when the mayor who recommends the budget is not distanced from the intricacy of the issues that become before the committee.

[Van der Kloot]: Remember, the mayor only gets one vote, not more, not less, than any other member.

[Van der Kloot]: Later, I hope to perhaps address some of the other issues.

[Van der Kloot]: So I wanted to address this issue of the autonomy of the school committee to pick their own officers or how that's done.

[Van der Kloot]: And I will tell you that this comes from my long years of experience.

[Van der Kloot]: And one of the things that I understand is that power is just so sweet.

[Van der Kloot]: And if you would, I have seen that selection process happen.

[Van der Kloot]: And I have seen very, very good people

[Van der Kloot]: who then decided they wanted to keep on being and locking out other members from getting an opportunity.

[Van der Kloot]: I think it's important that members of the body have an opportunity to be either, which now would be the chair and secretary.

[Van der Kloot]: So if you would, that part of this comes from trying not to prevent fiefdoms.

[Van der Kloot]: Now, in the original charter, when I went to look at it, there was practically nothing about the school committee.

[Van der Kloot]: And in this charter, there's not as much as I would like, quite honestly, because at the recommendation of the Collins Center, quite a bit was taken out that we had talked about.

[Van der Kloot]: While I certainly understand the argument of having the body be autonomous and make their own decisions, I've also seen the negative.

[Van der Kloot]: And we have to look at both positions.

[Van der Kloot]: Now we're talking about chair and secretary.

[Van der Kloot]: Now the secretary role includes signing the bills on behalf of the school committee.

[Van der Kloot]: That is the current structure that we use in Medford is the secretary of the school committee signs the bills.

[Van der Kloot]: And once upon a time, I signed the bills for 10 years in a row.

[Van der Kloot]: It is a damn good thing that I'm honest, because nobody should have ever possibly wanted me to sign the bills for 10 years in a row.

[Van der Kloot]: And of course, I definitely invited my colleagues in and said, please take a look at what I'm doing, because I want to make sure that somebody else has eyes on this besides me.

[Van der Kloot]: It is not always a popular position because it takes time, but there is also an added stipend.

[Van der Kloot]: And there are added stipends for the position of what used to be vice chair and secretary.

[Van der Kloot]: And in fact, I saw the recommendations that I think Councilor Bears put out.

[Van der Kloot]: It's significant money.

[Van der Kloot]: I think it was like an $8,000 stipend for these positions.

[Van der Kloot]: I am wanting members to have the opportunity to do these different roles and not just keep it so that one person develops power and fiefdom.

[Van der Kloot]: Now, if you read it, a key word is consecutive.

[Van der Kloot]: I didn't say you can only do it once when we wrote this language and you don't get to do it again.

[Van der Kloot]: I just said you can't do it consecutively.

[Van der Kloot]: So you can do it in, you could be the chair in year one, year three, year five.

[Van der Kloot]: You could be the secretary then.

[Van der Kloot]: You could alternate those two.

[Van der Kloot]: So it's far from perfect, but I think it's better than not saying anything at all.

[Van der Kloot]: So that is the thinking behind it.

[Van der Kloot]: That is the rationale as we spoke on the committee of saying, look, do we put this in now personally, and maybe it's my mistake because I didn't catch it.

[Van der Kloot]: But I didn't think about it, I have experience as a school committee member, not as a city Councilor.

[Van der Kloot]: Because quite honestly, I think you guys ought to rotate your chair, too.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't like the idea of having one person be the chair every single year.

[Van der Kloot]: I'd much rather see it rotate around members.

[Van der Kloot]: And that isn't to say that I don't want to see Council Bears not be the chair.

[Van der Kloot]: at all.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm happy if he's chair one, three and five or whatever.

[Van der Kloot]: You get my point.

[Van der Kloot]: I just don't think that one person in our city government should have a lock on these positions.

[Van der Kloot]: I think it's important to let other members have a chance to get the experience of leading and being in that role.

[Van der Kloot]: That's where it comes from.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, I need to take a look because it was originally that's what our discussion was.

[Van der Kloot]: The intent of being is that it would just, you know, because every two years you've got different people on the committee anyway.

[Van der Kloot]: So there's change, you know, so, but the idea was that not one person wouldn't have a lock on it.

[Van der Kloot]: So I'll take a look.

[Van der Kloot]: Well then don't put anything in the jar.

[Van der Kloot]: I mean, you know, that's always a possibility.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, you know, the, I don't, I don't know.

[Van der Kloot]: how else to go about it.

[Van der Kloot]: I understand people don't necessarily agree with me, but some of those people may be the same people who have a lock on positions now.

[Van der Kloot]: And I don't know if that's true or not.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't want that.

[Van der Kloot]: But I'm just saying that for me, I am looking at not creating fiefdoms of power.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm looking at ways of giving other members opportunities.

[Van der Kloot]: It's pretty simple.

[Van der Kloot]: To me, it's common sense.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: Councilor Tseng, did you want me to go ahead to address that?

[Van der Kloot]: Well, I think we certainly considered all the different options.

[Van der Kloot]: We were concerned that not everybody, you know, if we looked over historically at where school committee members, what

[Van der Kloot]: uh wards they had lived in and we we were concerned in and and the way that our particular uh city there um we don't have a school in each ward so we were looking at school placements and how that worked and it it doesn't really correspond in any way and we were concerned i mean um

[Van der Kloot]: Sometimes there aren't that many people interested in running for school committee.

[Van der Kloot]: It's a very taxing job.

[Van der Kloot]: It takes a long time.

[Van der Kloot]: In the past, the stipends were always considerably lower.

[Van der Kloot]: We don't want someone running for position just because they want to collect the stipend.

[Van der Kloot]: And so after we discussed all of the different options, and then we started trying to say, well, if we were doing ward representation, what would happen if we had wards where no one wanted to be on the school committee?

[Van der Kloot]: And we were concerned about that.

[Van der Kloot]: You know, after many different looking at this, this to us seemed to be an opportunity to certainly increase representation from different districts in the city, but also minimize other potential problems.

[Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Van der Kloot]: There we go, thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: Councilor Tseng, I just wanted to come back for just a second to say I became a little nervous as I was listening to the discussion that all of a sudden the comparison was to what the school committee subcommittee proposed.

[Van der Kloot]: in our particular part of the school committee.

[Van der Kloot]: And it is different than what was proposed for city Councilors.

[Van der Kloot]: That was because we did see that there was different roles and really in some ways different populations.

[Van der Kloot]: I wanted to say that I came slowly toward representation, but ultimately voted and supported it because as a member of the committee, and having attended many of the information sessions,

[Van der Kloot]: and listening to people and talking to people in other communities, as well as having the discussions that we'll talk more about in terms specifically about the school committee, I heard from our citizens a great interest in having ward representation.

[Van der Kloot]: I think, and as I served on the committee, you know, you could go nuts doing this because there's always one more thing you can do and one more thing and make it better.

[Van der Kloot]: And I absolutely believe that we're really all interested here in trying to come up with a good, positive solution.

[Van der Kloot]: And we all understand that it's really time.

[Van der Kloot]: So there's, you know,

[Van der Kloot]: the weighing between how much do we go back to the drawing board and do another something and another something and how much we move is, you know, the question is there.

[Van der Kloot]: I just want to let the committee know that I came to appreciate ward representation, even though as someone who had ran and served our city for a long time, I loved representing the whole city, but there was much to be said for those other discussions and I don't want

[Van der Kloot]: the fact that we chose something different to put forward to you for the school committee to hamper the discussion or make anybody think that I was not a proponent for what the committee put forth overall.

[Van der Kloot]: They haven't had one for a very long time.

[Van der Kloot]: At the vocational school, they asked us for a brand new upgraded 3D printer.

[Van der Kloot]: and a much more expensive one than they've had, and we funded that at your last meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: We have an after-school cooking club at the Andrews.

[Van der Kloot]: We think it's a great idea.

[Van der Kloot]: working on international food.

[Van der Kloot]: And so we're funding some of their expenses.

[Van der Kloot]: So that's the thing we do.

[Van der Kloot]: They're not earth shattering, but they sure are fun.

[Van der Kloot]: And we think that they add to a student's enjoyment.

[Van der Kloot]: And we know from the feedback that we get that the teachers really present, appreciate having another funding source that they can ask to for money.

[Van der Kloot]: One of the funds we just gave out was for 50 bucks.

[Van der Kloot]: But we've been working sort of behind the scenes for roughly seven years.

[Van der Kloot]: I actually have to go back and figure it out sometime.

[Van der Kloot]: The Medford Educational Foundation was started

[Van der Kloot]: way long ago, maybe 20 plus 25 years, by the late, great Bob Gilligan, attorney Bob Gilligan, and Gene Bralt, or Len Bralt, excuse me.

[Van der Kloot]: It lasted for a couple of years, and then it kind of went by the wayside.

[Van der Kloot]: Ann Kasuth and I resurrected it about seven or eight years ago, and we've been working behind the scenes ever since that time.

[Van der Kloot]: Today, tonight, on behalf of the Medford Educational Foundation, I am writing you to formally ask you to accept a donation to the Medford Public Schools to cover the specific grants that we are able to fund at this time.

[Van der Kloot]: Each year, we have two times during the year where we accept applications from teachers, and we ask them either to apply for a grant of zero to $200

[Van der Kloot]: or another grant from $200 to $2,000.

[Van der Kloot]: And we accept those grants.

[Van der Kloot]: And then as a body, we deliberate on the grants.

[Van der Kloot]: We check out with the schools that

[Van der Kloot]: The projects are consistent with the educational values and direction that the school system must go in or is going in.

[Van der Kloot]: And Diane Caldwell, who of course you guys all know, has been extremely helpful in being a partner with us and volunteering her time so that we could make these grants.

[Van der Kloot]: This December, we received over 38 requests from teachers who outlined specific projects or requests that they believe would enhance their students' learning experience.

[Van der Kloot]: While we would have loved to fund each and every one of them, we met as a group and decided which grants we could fund in their entirety, which grants we could partially fund, and sadly, which grants we couldn't afford at this time.

[Van der Kloot]: The December application cycle yielded more than $24,000 in requests, and we have been able to fund $13,058.86.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, just because I think it's appropriate to ask.

[Van der Kloot]: So let's take the $50,000 figure.

[Van der Kloot]: Given our expenditures to date, is it realistic to that we will be able to cover that expense given our budget expenses so far this year?

[Van der Kloot]: And I guess I'm asking Mr. Murphy that.

[Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Van der Kloot]: So I guess my question is, are our expenses running as expected, or are they widely more than we expected?

[Van der Kloot]: And should we be concerned about spending a significant amount of money?

[Van der Kloot]: Now, again, part of the problem is it may not be significant.

[Van der Kloot]: Maybe it's $10,000.

[Van der Kloot]: Maybe it's $12,000.

[Van der Kloot]: Great.

[Van der Kloot]: That's exactly what I was hoping you'd say.

[Van der Kloot]: Yeah, so thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: I think this sounds like very interesting and challenging work.

[Van der Kloot]: A couple of questions.

[Van der Kloot]: First, where were the engagement specialists housed in the schools?

[Van der Kloot]: Have we found offices for them all?

[Van der Kloot]: Because I can't believe that wasn't a challenge.

[Van der Kloot]: That was actually my second question was, you know, part of this is, is that they have to find their place within the schools, right, and to a point that Mr. Murphy made earlier.

[Van der Kloot]: Sometimes they've had to be utilized as coverage, but frankly, that sometimes is the time when you really get to see a broad view of students, and this can be very very valuable to

[Van der Kloot]: whoever works in the school so I actually think, especially at the beginning of the year.

[Van der Kloot]: That's an asset, even, you know, I understand it's time consuming, but it does allow someone to come in.

[Van der Kloot]: Now, my other question is so let's suppose said person, one of your reengagement specialist is something that we as adults understand the terminology.

[Van der Kloot]: What will the kids call these individuals?

[Van der Kloot]: Where do they fit in there?

[Van der Kloot]: I guess, you know, I'm just thinking for the youngest kids, something like a,

[Van der Kloot]: helping hand or something.

[Van der Kloot]: Yeah, you know something, something that something, even a helper I'm a helper that someplace I can just see them being in the school and trying to say, how do they define their place with the title, which is child friendly helper.

[Van der Kloot]: Anyway, just curious.

[Van der Kloot]: Just to clarify, so the students were moved, or was this an event where the teacher came in and found the water in the?

[Van der Kloot]: After the evening or weekend?

[Van der Kloot]: And the students were moved?

[Van der Kloot]: And then are the ceiling tile has been replaced at this point?

[Van der Kloot]: Are the kids back in that original classroom?

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, they're definitely back in there.

[Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Van der Kloot]: And this was one classroom at the McGlynn.

[Van der Kloot]: Is that correct?

[Van der Kloot]: Three.

[Van der Kloot]: Three.

[Van der Kloot]: Three kindergarten classrooms were affected.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: So one of the things which I'm just going to comment on is that I feel almost like our rules and regulations about how we address something, I think we're unfortunate in this case because we had a member of the public come up

[Van der Kloot]: and show some photos, and it says we're not supposed to respond.

[Van der Kloot]: And yet it was very clear to me that the superintendent had been down, that she knew a lot about this, that you knew a lot about this, but because it says we're not supposed to respond, that family who was sitting here

[Van der Kloot]: walked away without any answers, just, and we did what we could do.

[Van der Kloot]: We said we referred it and asked you for information today.

[Van der Kloot]: To me, there's a process thing, which is difficult for me, only because if we're following our rules, then we're not responding to a person with an immediate concern.

[Van der Kloot]: And I think it doesn't speak to the strength of the administrative team who knew everything.

[Van der Kloot]: You could have answered the questions last week with a follow-up today or whatever.

[Van der Kloot]: But I find that to be, as someone who's been on the committee for a long time, a very difficult place.

[Van der Kloot]: And I understand we're following procedure.

[Van der Kloot]: To the end, the only thing I could think of, frankly,

[Van der Kloot]: to the superintendent is to say, please be more proactive.

[Van der Kloot]: This was a situation you knew about.

[Van der Kloot]: It probably should have been in your report, so we could have spoken about it.

[Van der Kloot]: So if something like that's the thing, the only thing my sort of plea to you is to be, I think you guys did everything right, that you were on top of the situation.

[Van der Kloot]: But unfortunately, when it was presented, because we were following our rules,

[Van der Kloot]: it didn't look like you were as on top of the situation as you actually were.

[Van der Kloot]: It doesn't, and it never will, because when things happen like that, it's going to be a problem for all of us.

[Van der Kloot]: But on the other hand, since we did know it was going to be on the agenda, if it had been included

[Van der Kloot]: In the superintendent's remarks, we could have said, we're going to hold that until later.

[Van der Kloot]: I mean, frankly, I'm trying to do a workaround around our rule, which makes sense for other reasons, but is sometimes challenging.

[Van der Kloot]: And I'm not going to be here to do it, but I am saying to my committee members, this is an interesting dilemma.

[Van der Kloot]: Because I guarantee you that when there's something like this particular problem, it's going to get to the committee.

[Van der Kloot]: I mean, it's going to get, you know, it's not a surprise.

[Van der Kloot]: Sure.

[Van der Kloot]: It's multiple questions.

[Van der Kloot]: Yep, air quality checks in the school buildings.

[Van der Kloot]: And she said that we were told that air filters would be replaced often.

[Van der Kloot]: Can we have an update on this?

[Van der Kloot]: If the filters are not replaced often, she says the air quality cannot be guaranteed.

[Van der Kloot]: She's specifically asking about air filters.

[Van der Kloot]: So would they just, I'm asking you, would they be changed around, say, December 1st again?

[Van der Kloot]: Quarterly.

[Van der Kloot]: Maybe you could just give us an update when that happens.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, second question.

[Van der Kloot]: School staff have ongoing concerns regarding the room temperature in classrooms.

[Van der Kloot]: Warm classrooms, she says, lead to more improper mask wearing.

[Van der Kloot]: Also, when you cannot feel the AC, it is hard to know if the air is blowing, which leads to worries about airflow.

[Van der Kloot]: Work requests have been repeatedly ignored, she says.

[Van der Kloot]: So please detail what staff need to do to get these concerns addressed, and please make sure it is communicated to all staff.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, number three, many teachers or staff at our school are interested in additional your air purification.

[Van der Kloot]: The PTO at our school would like to purchase box fans with more 13 filters.

[Van der Kloot]: They are under $100 each but most of our classroom teachers are interested.

[Van der Kloot]: Can we request the use of code would bend to put toward this.

[Van der Kloot]: For equity sake, we would like this offer to all school buildings, our PTO will also put some funds toward this is their formal process to request coded funds.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: Fourth and lastly, can we have an update on staffing issues?

[Van der Kloot]: Are we close to returning to testing twice per week?

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, I received one more letter, just just as it came in as you were speaking.

[Van der Kloot]: It says, this is from Ingrid Mercado 131 budget.

[Van der Kloot]: Hello, I'd like to comment about the idea presented by Mr. Murphy of not having a standing COVID update in the agenda every meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: I think COVID topics are important and the public needs to be able to ask questions and get answers.

[Van der Kloot]: In my experience, school committee meetings are the only way to get these answers.

[Van der Kloot]: In the past, I've sent multiple questions to administration and I haven't received answers.

[Van der Kloot]: She notes nurses at the school level are fantastic and give us great information during our PTO meeting, but sometimes we want answers at the district level.

[Van der Kloot]: We can't see it at all, Peter.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: Could you just clarify?

[Van der Kloot]: So the test has already been given to students K to 12?

[Van der Kloot]: Did you still have a...

[Van der Kloot]: No.

[Van der Kloot]: Oh, okay.

[Van der Kloot]: There is a dress code is in the student handbooks, is at least mentioned in the student handbooks.

[Van der Kloot]: So that would be a starting point.

[Van der Kloot]: The school committee is supposed to approve the handbooks.

[Van der Kloot]: So it's just a point of that it's generally been

[Van der Kloot]: there's been discussions over the dress code for many years at many different times.

[Van der Kloot]: And I certainly support looking at it and updating it, but it's not like it's never been discussed.

[Van der Kloot]: Well, the refinement is that there's always been

[Van der Kloot]: the understanding that the policy that we approved that the the handbooks and that becomes what you're saying is we don't have a separate one in our policy handbook.

[Van der Kloot]: Well we're quibbling over it but I'm just mentioning that it's in the handbook.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: I think I should probably read them at this point.

[Van der Kloot]: Is that all right?

[Van der Kloot]: That's fine.

[Van der Kloot]: The first one is from

[Van der Kloot]: Christina McCourty 24 North Street.

[Van der Kloot]: She writes dear members of the school committee.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm the parent of two elementary school students and I'm writing with a few questions.

[Van der Kloot]: Do you want to take this one by one or if we could.

[Van der Kloot]: She worked on weekends around the clock to make sure that our students and teachers were safe.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you so much.

[Van der Kloot]: We took a roll call.

[Van der Kloot]: Before we do that, after that, as we're taking things out of order, I would ask that we move on to the presentation

[Van der Kloot]: of the advisory committee.

[Van der Kloot]: Mayor, I am happy to stay here to get to the entire agenda, no matter how late we go.

[Van der Kloot]: But in the meantime, we have an audience.

[Van der Kloot]: And we know why they're here.

[Van der Kloot]: We have an advisory council.

[Van der Kloot]: We know why that we're here.

[Van der Kloot]: We've already asked them graciously, not really asked, but

[Van der Kloot]: They graciously sat here for our wonderful presentation to Toni Wray.

[Van der Kloot]: We wanna take up our seventh graders and that I think it's only appropriate.

[Van der Kloot]: I guarantee you to my colleague, we will get to everything on the agenda.

[Van der Kloot]: No one's gonna rush out of here.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: The only thing is, I wondered whether we should specify one, because if there's one or more, or because sometimes if you're putting in one, putting in a second one might not be that.

[Van der Kloot]: So I don't want to limit it.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: So this is our rubric, and it was used by our committee to evaluate the names of the submissions.

[Van der Kloot]: The rubric outlined three different criteria.

[Van der Kloot]: the potential for the name to bring the community together, two, the potential for the name to stand as a role model for Medford students, and three, the potential for the name to represent Medford community's proud history.

[Van der Kloot]: Each one of the criteria had a scoring range from one to four, four being the highest a name could receive in any category, and one being the lowest score that a name should have received.

[Van der Kloot]: Thus, the top score of any one suggestion that they could receive is a 12, and any name with a 12 would be significant to multiple historically marginalized groups and not polarizing, known for exceptional deeds, community involvement, or contribution to society with a historical notable legacy that would last decades, or if it wasn't a person, it would still have historical significance that would last decades.

[Van der Kloot]: And lastly, if it was a person,

[Van der Kloot]: They would have lived in Medford with a Medford specific reputation, or if it was not a person, it would have a long standing ties to Medford with a positive history.

[Van der Kloot]: Our public participation process.

[Van der Kloot]: After all of the names were scored, the top scoring 15 names were to move on with the public participation.

[Van der Kloot]: However, due to a tie, we ended up with a top 17 names to move forward.

[Van der Kloot]: And then after looking at the list, we realized we had accidentally removed a name that should have been considered.

[Van der Kloot]: So we therefore added that name on to continue with the process, leaving us with 18 names to present to the public.

[Van der Kloot]: On May 11th, the committee adopted and formalized a process of how we should receive public input on those 18 names as outlined in a resolution brought forward by Heinrich Ginnies.

[Van der Kloot]: And a subcommittee was established to create the public input form.

[Van der Kloot]: And the survey was open for one week to collect written responses for or against any of the 18 names.

[Van der Kloot]: The survey itself was translated into Spanish, Haitian Creole, Arabic, and Portuguese.

[Van der Kloot]: There were hard copies also made available at Medford City Hall and the superintendent's office.

[Van der Kloot]: And overall, the committee received over 1,200 online responses and 39 paper submissions.

[Van der Kloot]: The top 18 names were also independently researched and rescored by each of the committee members.

[Van der Kloot]: via the process previously described by the rubric, all 23 members of the advisory committee did this.

[Van der Kloot]: The scores were then collected, averaged, and ranked as one point for the committee members to consider.

[Van der Kloot]: The committee then moved forward to reduce the finalists down to the

[Van der Kloot]: Using an adopted process as outlined and brought forth by Patrick McCabe, the committee started with a list of names in alphabetical order, and if a committee member had stated that that name was their top three, that name would remain in consideration.

[Van der Kloot]: If no one on the committee said they would include that name in their top three, that name was stricken from the list.

[Van der Kloot]: This reduced the official list down from 18 to 13 names,

[Van der Kloot]: And next, every committee member was given up to three minutes to advocate for which nominee or nominees they thought should be sent forward to the school committee based on their own research, the rubric and public input.

[Van der Kloot]: Each committee member voted for one of the nominees.

[Van der Kloot]: And after the first round of votes were recorded, only three of the candidates had received a vote.

[Van der Kloot]: And a motion put forth by Paul Donato Jr.

[Van der Kloot]: was made that we should just accept those three and send them forth.

[Van der Kloot]: And that was adopted and the three names that received votes were on the board.

[Van der Kloot]: And so our first few names that, these three names were Missituk, Jean Barry Sutherland, and Belinda Sutton.

[Van der Kloot]: The first of the three names here for you tonight is Missituk.

[Van der Kloot]: The land that the city of Medford sits on was inhabited by the Massachusetts tribe and other Native Americans for thousands of years.

[Van der Kloot]: The indigenous people that lived on the land called the river Missituk, which means Great Tidal River.

[Van der Kloot]: As English colonists came to the area, the name of the river was altered in a more familiar English word, Mystic.

[Van der Kloot]: The river has been very important throughout the history of Medford, and it was used for fishing and for water by the indigenous tribe, and then by the colonists, and it also became essential for trade.

[Van der Kloot]: It became a subject of poems, such as, Over the River and Through the Wood, and Paul Revere's Ride.

[Van der Kloot]: This river has been a source of community pride for centuries.

[Van der Kloot]: The Missituk River,

[Van der Kloot]: as previously mentioned, has been bringing people together.

[Van der Kloot]: It was a source of the food and water for indigenous tribes and the first colonists.

[Van der Kloot]: It then became a place that allowed Medford to take part in trade industry, being a port and preparing goods to ship out and even building ships.

[Van der Kloot]: The city of Medford grew because of the Mistook River.

[Van der Kloot]: And today, the river is used for walking, hiking, boating, fishing, and other various community events.

[Van der Kloot]: There is a widespread effort underway to continue to work to restore the river and the land surrounding it.

[Van der Kloot]: And by using the Native American name, Misutuk, we are taking time to honor those who had originally inhabited these lands and taking a step to acknowledge the past and as we do this, stepping into the future.

[Van der Kloot]: These are just three responses that we received from the community input survey.

[Van der Kloot]: There were so many wonderful responses.

[Van der Kloot]: And even though that this was not a vote, all of these responses were used and considered and provided the committee wonderful information into getting us to these final three names.

[Van der Kloot]: These three quotes here really exemplified why Missittook is a positive influence, not only for the city and for the students of the school,

[Van der Kloot]: but also for the rest of the children in the community.

[Van der Kloot]: Some of the feedback expressed that it was a reflection of the river and how the river has been a focal point for our community for centuries.

[Van der Kloot]: People also shared that it acknowledged the native people for who originally inhabited this land.

[Van der Kloot]: And it also provided a physical connection between our past and our present.

[Van der Kloot]: It was also shared that people liked it because it wasn't a single person.

[Van der Kloot]: but rather it celebrated a shared space and an aspect of a physical environment.

[Van der Kloot]: And lastly, Missittook represents Medford's proud history.

[Van der Kloot]: As previously mentioned, the Missittook has been here long before Medford has even existed.

[Van der Kloot]: The Missittook watershed was home to the indigenous people of Massachusetts prior to colonization of the area by the Europeans.

[Van der Kloot]: The name may have morphed into Mystic, but it does not diminish the role or the value of the Missitook River and what it has played in building Medford by providing resources of not only food, but also trade.

[Van der Kloot]: The river powered tide mills that allowed for the process of corn, tobacco, textiles, and wood.

[Van der Kloot]: It was the home of the first bridge over the river, allowing the city to play a key part in the founding of this nation.

[Van der Kloot]: The river is also the subject of well-known poems and stories.

[Van der Kloot]: And while the river may now be known as Mystic, the name Mistituk gives nod to those who came before us, honoring them and acknowledging their language and homelands.

[Van der Kloot]: It's a reminder that Medford's history didn't start when the Europeans came here.

[Van der Kloot]: It began long before the first boats arrived.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, so at the present the 27 letters have ballooned over 40.

[Van der Kloot]: So I'm going to I'm going to condense them where appropriate.

[Van der Kloot]: first from, and I'm starting from the ones that, the first one that came in was from Carrie Parker of 6 Hurlcross Ave.

[Van der Kloot]: She said, I am writing to you because I want to support the renaming of the Columbus Elementary School at tonight's school committee meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: The school committee set up a transparent process carefully naming the committee, and the committee did extensive work to identify three possible names that reflect Medford.

[Van der Kloot]: They are inclusive, positive, and anti-racist.

[Van der Kloot]: I am proud that Medford is taking a step forward.

[Van der Kloot]: and look forward to seeing the committee's work completed.

[Van der Kloot]: And, should I do one more?

[Van der Kloot]: Next letter I received was from Ellery Klein.

[Van der Kloot]: Please know that I am supporting you tonight as you face a contentious meeting regarding the school name change for the Columbus Elementary.

[Van der Kloot]: I would like to just offer one thought.

[Van der Kloot]: A friend of color told me she felt that naming the school after an enslaved person, Belinda Sutton, was not inspiring for the kids of color in the building.

[Van der Kloot]: While I initially liked the story as Mrs. Sutton used her obviously strong powers of persuasive writing and the US justice system of the time to earn her freedom and a recompense for her

[Van der Kloot]: experience of one of the worst injustices a human being can face and hopefully went on to a better life and freedom, I was willing to hear and absorb this perspective from my friend.

[Van der Kloot]: While I do think it shows agency and power on the part of Miss Sutton, and one could argue that Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman were also enslaved, yet nevertheless,

[Van der Kloot]: inspiring fears, I do want to make sure that we have heard from enough voices of color to feel comfortable choosing Belinda Sutton as the name should we choose to do so.

[Van der Kloot]: If the voices in support of the beloved Medford-educated Jean Barry Sutherland are still unanimous and no hidden secrets have emerged, I also think this is a fine choice.

[Van der Kloot]: However, I would urge the mayor to set firm guidelines, which we have.

[Van der Kloot]: I fully remain in support of the name change of the Columbus to one that is more in line with justice, freedom, hope, and kindness.

[Van der Kloot]: Regards, Ellery Klein.

[Van der Kloot]: We have begun each performance with a land acknowledgement, recognizing the often forgotten people who lived here before European colonization.

[Van der Kloot]: Another of the choices has been Linda Sutton would serve as an ongoing acknowledgement of the black people who were kidnapped from their homes in Africa and forcibly brought to the country and made to work as slaves.

[Van der Kloot]: Your third choice, Jean Barry Sutherland would honor the first principal of the school and a person who had a big impact on a number of lives.

[Van der Kloot]: On the surface, it seems like a fine choice,

[Van der Kloot]: However, given the larger historical, cultural, and societal context in which we are living, it would also be a choice that serves to reinforce the status quo.

[Van der Kloot]: I ask you, by the way, don't, after I speak,

[Van der Kloot]: Don't clap or catcall and don't do the same for them either.

[Van der Kloot]: Let us have an intelligent discussion now.

[Van der Kloot]: that is motivating me for my discussion is hearing some of the portion of our community who felt disenfranchised by our removing the name Columbus.

[Van der Kloot]: But anyway, um,

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Tuck got 107 votes.

[Van der Kloot]: Jean Barry got 84.

[Van der Kloot]: Belinda Sutton got 86.

[Van der Kloot]: So if I look at 84 and 86, that's 170.

[Van der Kloot]: So then there is, you know, it was a three-way vote.

[Van der Kloot]: It wasn't a two-way vote.

[Van der Kloot]: Now, of course, democratically, if it's, you know, whoever gets the highest vote, I am stuck with that because I wonder if Jean Barry would be saying, go with the kids.

[Van der Kloot]: And that's my only problem.

[Van der Kloot]: But I knew Jean Barry.

[Van der Kloot]: I knew her when she was selected to represent Medford in Nobioka, okay?

[Van der Kloot]: That was an incredible honor.

[Van der Kloot]: Two educators were going off to represent Medford in our sister city of Japan.

[Van der Kloot]: And for years, we also had students who were selected, the highest students who got to go and visit Nobioka, our sister city, and in return, they came here.

[Van der Kloot]: Jean was the first one who got to go.

[Van der Kloot]: It was fabulous.

[Van der Kloot]: I knew Jean when she was a teacher at the Dane, and I knew Jean when she welcomed me into the Columbus School.

[Van der Kloot]: And she said, as she looked around her classroom, her school, as she toured me, and she said, look at this, isn't this great?

[Van der Kloot]: Look how many students we have from all different countries and all different places.

[Van der Kloot]: Jean Barry always had a smile across her face.

[Van der Kloot]: She was inclusive.

[Van der Kloot]: She was involved.

[Van der Kloot]: You can't really say a bad thing about Jean.

[Van der Kloot]: Someone said it.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm lucky.

[Van der Kloot]: I knew her.

[Van der Kloot]: I wish everybody knew her.

[Van der Kloot]: She has been at the school.

[Van der Kloot]: There is a tribute to Jean Barry at the school and has been since her death with the sign saying Jean Barry.

[Van der Kloot]: That happened because she was so valued.

[Van der Kloot]: And when she died, man, it was awfully hard.

[Van der Kloot]: I remember how many people were crying.

[Van der Kloot]: It was such a loss in our community.

[Van der Kloot]: So I'm gonna support, that would be my first choice, would be Jean Barry.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't want you to clap or anything else like that because you agree with me, okay?

[Van der Kloot]: Unfortunately, sometimes in here, there's a feeling that it's been divisive.

[Van der Kloot]: Jean Barry was an educator.

[Van der Kloot]: As I pick an educator as a member of the school committee, I am upholding every educator that we have had in this community.

[Van der Kloot]: Every teacher, every principal, every superintendent, everybody who has committed themselves to education, to me, we can look and we can say to the kids, education is so important.

[Van der Kloot]: that this community recognizes an educator on the name of one of our buildings.

[Van der Kloot]: That is the perspective that I come from and that I bring.

[Van der Kloot]: I think that the other names are fantastic.

[Van der Kloot]: I hope we utilize them in our community in a different way.

[Van der Kloot]: One last thing.

[Van der Kloot]: I take exception.

[Van der Kloot]: to the person and the commentary that has happened that has said this school committee didn't function about our education.

[Van der Kloot]: We only worried about this.

[Van der Kloot]: I need to say this to you as someone who has been on the school committee for many, many years.

[Van der Kloot]: This school committee worked hard

[Van der Kloot]: This school committee, yes, we had this.

[Van der Kloot]: It was at the right time and we could debate that till we were blue in the face.

[Van der Kloot]: We don't need to go there.

[Van der Kloot]: But what we do need to let you know is in the month of March, this school committee had 23 meetings.

[Van der Kloot]: Earlier, when we started out, we took Toni Wray, our nurse, and we held her up because she's been such an incredible force.

[Van der Kloot]: This school committee, our administrative people, our school committee members, we're not looking for your praise, but to sit here and hear you say you didn't care about our kids is simply wrong.

[Van der Kloot]: And if I don't say it,

[Van der Kloot]: okay, I cannot live with the feeling of just sort of sitting here and nodding my head and saying, oh, yeah, right.

[Van der Kloot]: That wasn't true.

[Van der Kloot]: I wasn't going to share this story because you never know how people take it.

[Van der Kloot]: My father

[Van der Kloot]: He grew up in Ireland, but always driving up Fulton Street.

[Van der Kloot]: I grew up at 350 Fulton Street, and my father always going up the hill, he would say, you know, Mia, long before us, there were Native Americans who walked up Fulton Street.

[Van der Kloot]: It wasn't called Fulton Street, obviously, but to Wright's Pond, and that's where they got their water.

[Van der Kloot]: And as a kid, it never really registered with me that there were people here before us.

[Van der Kloot]: And now it kind of came full circle for me that this is an opportunity to recognize the Native Americans and the tribes that were here.

[Van der Kloot]: before us, long before us.

[Van der Kloot]: So, Mr. Murphy, you and I spent considerable time today discussing the issue that my colleague brought up at the top of this meeting with the transportation for the high school students.

[Van der Kloot]: And really what we come down to, if I'm clear on it, is that no final decision has been made except that you are working towards the fact that the school committee wants to provide transportation.

[Van der Kloot]: One thing I thought about after our discussion was whether students would still be able to buy bus passes if they were so inclined.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: And just to follow up, during the course of the discussion, I expressed great concern that the Eastern bus projection that we would be able to go down a bus was a terrific surprise to me.

[Van der Kloot]: Now, it is true that we have less students currently than we did.

[Van der Kloot]: It is unclear exactly how many students will be returning to us.

[Van der Kloot]: But that is, I just, I think that we need to keep what our budgeting generous in this area because I believe, I just know from the past that all of a sudden we have requests from the woodwork and it's very, very difficult to take back something that you've given before.

[Van der Kloot]: So that's a concern.

[Van der Kloot]: On the bright side, I do wanna mention that there were so many things in this budget which are positives.

[Van der Kloot]: For instance, I'll just pick a small one.

[Van der Kloot]: In the world languages, we are going to introduce French in the sixth grade level and textbooks for that have been provided for.

[Van der Kloot]: There's also textbooks in the science area, and I didn't go through all of them, but I don't want members of the public to think that there aren't, in fact, major upgrades in many, many areas.

[Van der Kloot]: On the other hand, there are some areas which I am a little concerned about.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm gonna go back to my fine arts where earlier I had asked many questions about this area.

[Van der Kloot]: I had been advocating strongly for a supervisor, a director position of fine arts.

[Van der Kloot]: After a discussion with the superintendent, it's clear that she's not yet ready to move on this.

[Van der Kloot]: And while I understand that in some ways, in other ways,

[Van der Kloot]: I still feel that the area is so critical in that social emotional well-being of life area.

[Van der Kloot]: So we aren't doing that right now, but I've certainly made it clear that my concerns in the future.

[Van der Kloot]: We'll be watching that very carefully.

[Van der Kloot]: However, given that that isn't happening, I was a little surprised not to see some of the smaller requests increase inventory of instruments, including ukuleles.

[Van der Kloot]: I had asked about the number of violins, being that we're going to be starting both

[Van der Kloot]: potentially two grade levels.

[Van der Kloot]: And some of those things I don't see funded.

[Van der Kloot]: So I wanted to ask about that.

[Van der Kloot]: And I also wanted to question, I assume that some of the other things that we talked about for science, I mean, excuse me, for summer enrichment programs are under the TBD sort because that's gonna come from ESSER funding?

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, could you go back and talk about the smaller bylines and fine arts at them?

[Van der Kloot]: So I assume that one perhaps is about transportation for the band.

[Van der Kloot]: So that one is in.

[Van der Kloot]: I guess one of the things is when I talk about and you mentioned ukuleles, but there's also

[Van der Kloot]: part of my real concern was the violin and the orchestra program, that while they're small numbers, and I certainly understand you can say, yes, they'll be covered in the course, that there were some of these that are, you know, really germane to the enjoyment of students.

[Van der Kloot]: And I think that enjoyment and going to school is, you know, a very important piece of it.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, the school committee received a letter this week from some of our CCSR students asking about our user fees.

[Van der Kloot]: And this has been something that over the years we've sought to reduce user fees.

[Van der Kloot]: Now, it's a fairly substantial number.

[Van der Kloot]: And perhaps, Mr. Murphy, do you know how much user fees bring in or approximately?

[Van der Kloot]: So anyway, this is certainly another concern.

[Van der Kloot]: I know that we have taken great pains to make sure that students who could not afford user fees were in fact waived, yet the students are bringing it before us.

[Van der Kloot]: So I realized that at this point now we've set our budget number.

[Van der Kloot]: We're also clearing that there's going to be some level of,

[Van der Kloot]: change yet in the budget as they normally are.

[Van der Kloot]: I certainly know that for years and years and years, the ideal thought would be that we would waive all user fees.

[Van der Kloot]: But it's always been a budget impact, just the way the transportation is and everything else.

[Van der Kloot]: and Maureen Lavin.

[Van der Kloot]: Rachel Puri discussed health education.

[Van der Kloot]: She gave us a presentation.

[Van der Kloot]: She mentioned that Medford is aligned to national standards.

[Van der Kloot]: DESE is editing the 1999 frameworks and will put it out for public opinion.

[Van der Kloot]: So because of that, that's why we're right now aligning to the national standards.

[Van der Kloot]: We use the Michigan model based K to 12.

[Van der Kloot]: We spoke about this

[Van der Kloot]: at some length later in the meeting as well.

[Van der Kloot]: In the elementary, social-emotional is taught by classroom teachers, which begins in kindergarten.

[Van der Kloot]: In third grade, discussions about bullying education begins.

[Van der Kloot]: And in fifth grade, we have introduction to puberty given by the nursing department using a Proctor and Gamble curriculum.

[Van der Kloot]: There are pre and post tests provided to assess student learning.

[Van der Kloot]: In middle school, the students have half a year of health and half a year in guidance.

[Van der Kloot]: Then we talked about some detail about the curriculum in each of the years.

[Van der Kloot]: And again, that there are pre and post assignments.

[Van der Kloot]: At high school health, it's taught by health teachers.

[Van der Kloot]: Again, it's half a year of health, half a year of physical education.

[Van der Kloot]: Freshman year is introduction to health, sophomore year is healthy decision making, junior year is healthy lifestyles, and senior year is transition to adulthood.

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Rousseau asked whether gender identity was covered in grade six to eight, and Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Perry answered that it was covered briefly in grade six.

[Van der Kloot]: National guidelines on sexuality and gender identity just changed and we're adapting to those.

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Rousseau followed, said that he was concerned it wasn't presented until senior year, but Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Perry assured us that it's also presented during the freshman year.

[Van der Kloot]: We also talked about the right language for consent.

[Van der Kloot]: And Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Perry said that the students are taught appropriate touch guidelines.

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Russo said, do we ever talk about sex in a positive way?

[Van der Kloot]: And Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Perry said that the age of consent is 16.

[Van der Kloot]: So we talk about abstinence to adhere to that guideline.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Graham questions about the Michigan model and spoke about her concern that a consumer product video is used to introduce puberty.

[Van der Kloot]: And there was quite a bit of discussion about this and seeing the hopos that we could see whether there is a better film or introduction that's out there.

[Van der Kloot]: And so that's sort of on the table to explore.

[Van der Kloot]: In physical education, in each of the grades, really introduction to basic skills and concepts.

[Van der Kloot]: One of the things that we talked about the most is what's needed.

[Van der Kloot]: We need to hire a middle school health teacher.

[Van der Kloot]: We need an adaptive PE teacher.

[Van der Kloot]: We need to provide professional development for sex education.

[Van der Kloot]: And we need to provide professional development for adaptive physical education for the entire physical education staff.

[Van der Kloot]: We did talk more about the adaptive PE and asked how we're meeting the needs of all of our students.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Perry said that some students say sub-separate, some go into full class, and we're looking into using something called the flash curriculum.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Graham followed and asked more questions about the Michigan model, and Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Perry assured us that it's a skills-based model.

[Van der Kloot]: And I remembered from our, when we,

[Van der Kloot]: used it when we approved it, there was a great deal of discussion about it at the time.

[Van der Kloot]: We do need to pay attention to the national standards until DESE updates theirs.

[Van der Kloot]: Girls are hitting puberty at younger ages, especially children of color.

[Van der Kloot]: Research tells us that we need to emphasize healthy eating.

[Van der Kloot]: One, with all due respect and after talking with many other Medford families who tune in to watch Medford Public School Committee meetings, we kindly ask that any and all subjects that do not pertain directly to Medford Public Schools, please be refrained from being discussed during the time of the meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: We as parents tune in each meeting to keep up and stay in touch with what is going on within our school system.

[Van der Kloot]: And we do not need updates on news stories that are going on within our nation that do not directly affect this school system.

[Van der Kloot]: Example, at the last meeting, the news of a 20-year-old man in Minneapolis who was shot by police when trying to flee while being arrested was discussed when this had nothing at all to do with the Medford public schools.

[Van der Kloot]: There was quite a list that was given and provided.

[Van der Kloot]: The Hill for Literacy, Crafting Minds, Dr. Nadine Gabb, Lexia training, Lexia Core 5 training, et cetera.

[Van der Kloot]: The Alexia Rapid is given at the Brooks, McGlynn, and Roberts.

[Van der Kloot]: And the NWEA Map Growth is given at the Columbus.

[Van der Kloot]: It says, dear superintendent and school committee members, I am writing to you as a parent of two elementary school children who are currently enrolled in the full remote learning at the Roberts and who will remain in remote learning for the rest of the school year.

[Van der Kloot]: I am very concerned that the students who plan to remain in the remote classes not be subjected to additional changes due to the April 5th shift to full-time in-person learning for the current hybrid students.

[Van der Kloot]: The remote teachers have spent the last six plus months working hard to create a classroom community and new daily routines in virtual learning.

[Van der Kloot]: While both of my boys are struggling with the virtual aspect of virtual learning, they love being a part of the classroom community and seeing the same classmates and teacher every day.

[Van der Kloot]: And as a parent, I know that the classroom routines keep them feeling grounded and secure.

[Van der Kloot]: If any of these things are changed now with less than a third of the year remaining, if students are regrouped and put with different classmates and or a new teacher, it will cause yet another major disruption in the lives of young children who are still living through an intensely difficult and traumatizing event.

[Van der Kloot]: Please do not make changes to the remote learning classrooms between now and the end of the school year."

[Van der Kloot]: That sentiment was shared and we received a

[Van der Kloot]: Yeah, so I need to understand what we need to decide tonight, because clearly there's a much larger

[Van der Kloot]: If in fact, at some future time, we envision a rebuilding or something.

[Van der Kloot]: And so I need to know just tonight, what decision we need to make?

[Van der Kloot]: Was this brought to us because we're trying to make a decision about whether we're gonna expend the money for the bathrooms?

[Van der Kloot]: Mayor, are we discussing the superintendent's contract now, or?

[Van der Kloot]: Hi, everybody.

[Van der Kloot]: Melanie?

[Van der Kloot]: I had sort of a question, comment, a little bit different than where you're going right there.

[Van der Kloot]: But just in terms of thinking about our kids, I know that last week I had occasion to have to go down to Mass General Hospital to see a friend.

[Van der Kloot]: And, you know, my reaction was there was all these people there.

[Van der Kloot]: What were they all doing there?

[Van der Kloot]: I was used to being in spaces that were very distant.

[Van der Kloot]: And all of a sudden there were lots of people.

[Van der Kloot]: Everybody's wearing masks and all that.

[Van der Kloot]: But, you know, I'm kind of wondering about kids.

[Van der Kloot]: And Stacey kind of veered in when you mentioned, you know, all the kids who've been on remote all the time.

[Van der Kloot]: But as we are looking for kids coming back into school who have been

[Van der Kloot]: given this message over and over again to keep their distance.

[Van der Kloot]: And now we're potentially going down and you know from 6 feet to 3 feet.

[Van der Kloot]: You know, I know how I reacted I and I've talked to other people and they've had similar reactions so what about kids.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm wondering about the short term the kids who are coming back in, you know, in the coming weeks to all of a sudden, you know, four day or five day learning.

[Van der Kloot]: you know, what we're thinking about and helping them adjust to this, more bodies.

[Van der Kloot]: And again, I'm really thinking about the kids who are prone to anxiety already.

[Van der Kloot]: Are we talking to teachers at all about, you know, having them be watching for this kind of anxiety?

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: So I just wanted to say to Dr. Cushing, it probably, so right now it sounds like the RFP is being prepared.

[Van der Kloot]: This is something that I think the Buildings and Grounds Subcommittee should also hear about.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm just saying, Peter, it's such exciting news now that it's back on the block.

[Van der Kloot]: So at some point, think that the Buildings and Grounds Subcommittee should

[Van der Kloot]: also be updated when you get the chance.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, I just want to mention that one of the real key issues about the after school program is personnel, is getting enough people to cover the students.

[Van der Kloot]: And that's been a real challenge.

[Van der Kloot]: So even if you look at enrollment, whatever, obviously the answer is to expand it, but expansion has been

[Van der Kloot]: tough because of the lack of people who want to apply for the relatively low paying jobs.

[Van der Kloot]: And it's also, it's not just the low pay, it's also the hours.

[Van der Kloot]: Many of our teachers have already worked a full day, so they're not particularly interested.

[Van der Kloot]: We've tried students coming in.

[Van der Kloot]: We certainly bring in a certain amount of high school students, but they need to be overseen.

[Van der Kloot]: So absolutely what we would like is to be able to expand it to accommodate every family who needs it, because that's the answer.

[Van der Kloot]: But it is challenging.

[Van der Kloot]: It sounds like we will need to be having a separate committee of the whole meeting for this topic.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: Yeah.

[Van der Kloot]: Three, once names are submitted for consideration, what is the next step in the process?

[Van der Kloot]: Four, what is the charge to the advisory committee?

[Van der Kloot]: What are we asking them to do?

[Van der Kloot]: Five is how is the chair or co-chairs chosen?

[Van der Kloot]: And six, does the advisory committee bring one choice to the school committee for confirmation or up to three for our selection?

[Van der Kloot]: Those are really the key points that member Brousseau and myself look at in different ways.

[Van der Kloot]: So that's just, I put that out.

[Van der Kloot]: I know there are many hands raised now, so I'm just gonna lay that out right now.

[Van der Kloot]: I would like to address one thing.

[Van der Kloot]: Many people are speaking about all the different things that the school committee faces, and that's absolutely true.

[Van der Kloot]: And I don't think that once we get through

[Van der Kloot]: the process and work it out.

[Van der Kloot]: And there will be some things that I speak to, like removing one piece, we'll get to it later, off of a school committee onto a committee of the whole instead.

[Van der Kloot]: You know, so I do, and the other thing which I think is key for me to say as the longest serving school committee member is, and when this first came up, I spoke to it.

[Van der Kloot]: Now, when this first came up, I will tell you, and I've said to other people, I wasn't happy with the process, okay?

[Van der Kloot]: Because at that first meeting, I felt confident in that, yes, I did feel there was a reason to change it.

[Van der Kloot]: You must remember that there was in light of a very

[Van der Kloot]: a spring of great reckoning and understanding of what was going on in our world and the racism that exists that we all saw with our own eyes.

[Van der Kloot]: And there is a context to this.

[Van der Kloot]: But 20 years ago, when we built the new schools, I can absolutely tell you that there was a discussion in the committee, in the Building the Future Committee of which I was part, about the naming of the schools.

[Van der Kloot]: And at that time, we were well aware that there were people who would much prefer it not to be the Columbus School.

[Van der Kloot]: I've kicked myself sometimes because I let that go, partially in deference to a community member who I had great respect for and who didn't want it to change.

[Van der Kloot]: But it's been a recurring

[Van der Kloot]: You know, maybe you haven't heard it, but I have over and over again.

[Van der Kloot]: I've heard it, I've had discussions down at the Columbus School with parents.

[Van der Kloot]: So it's not that this just popped up and there's been, it's not been part of our discussion.

[Van der Kloot]: It has been particularly for parents whose children attend the Columbus School.

[Van der Kloot]: And that certainly isn't to say that everybody agrees, but it's certainly been there.

[Van der Kloot]: So the time has to do with the timeline that she's suggesting is part of the discussion that we'll have.

[Van der Kloot]: We're sort of talking two different things.

[Van der Kloot]: I too, after I worked out my resolution, believes that it would be great to have more time, which is to say a number of weeks more to come to the conclusion of this.

[Van der Kloot]: I've built in and will talk to my committee about saying that I think that once we put the advisory council together and they begin their work, that they are the ones who will need to be able to say to us, hey, we need eight more weeks, or we need 12 more weeks, or we think this has to be the timeline.

[Van der Kloot]: But that's a discussion that as we work out the particulars of this.

[Van der Kloot]: The other thing is the reality of it is, and we just have to say this, and it's just blunt.

[Van der Kloot]: When people are saying they haven't been heard, we have heard them.

[Van der Kloot]: But unfortunately, we don't necessarily agree with them.

[Van der Kloot]: We are not agreeing to change, to not change the name.

[Van der Kloot]: So people keep on saying, you haven't heard us.

[Van der Kloot]: Well, we are hearing you.

[Van der Kloot]: And quite honestly, I mean, I had some great discussions and I was really moved at one point by one person who told me what Columbus Day meant in his family.

[Van der Kloot]: And I listened and I heard that.

[Van der Kloot]: I've heard other people say we're erasing history.

[Van der Kloot]: We're still going to teach our kids about Columbus.

[Van der Kloot]: Paul has a process where we wheedle them down.

[Van der Kloot]: But he had it that the school committee would wheedle down the number.

[Van der Kloot]: And I found that confusing.

[Van der Kloot]: And I thought that the whole intent of the advisory committee was, in fact, to vet the names.

[Van der Kloot]: I did not feel that I could receive the names on a Friday, April 23, and in our Monday meeting, April 26.

[Van der Kloot]: be willing or able to then only send to the committee my top four choices.

[Van der Kloot]: It's a very significant difference on how we approach this question.

[Van der Kloot]: Yeah, just to answer that.

[Van der Kloot]: And on so what basis am I going from 300 to four?

[Van der Kloot]: It's just not real.

[Van der Kloot]: Perhaps, you know, when you have multiple devices and then they close on you.

[Van der Kloot]: This one's Paul's, sorry.

[Van der Kloot]: Anyway, would that be acceptable?

[Van der Kloot]: Mayor, can I talk about that for a minute?

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, please do.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: First, I have a paragraph about participation by the Columbus School staff and students.

[Van der Kloot]: And it's a separate paragraph says in recognition that the staff and students of the Columbus school are dedicated to their school.

[Van der Kloot]: The school committee requests the principal to create a representative group of staff to solicit input from their colleagues.

[Van der Kloot]: Additionally, student input is highly desirable.

[Van der Kloot]: And if it is feasible, student participation will be encouraged in any way the principal deems to be workable in this very short period of time.

[Van der Kloot]: The goal of both staff and student input is to come up with three to five names to submit for consideration to the advisory committee.

[Van der Kloot]: The names will be submitted by April 26th.

[Van der Kloot]: So we're saying

[Van der Kloot]: to the principal, there's only four weeks.

[Van der Kloot]: We had originally envisioned a much greater, longer period where we were gonna get student education and input.

[Van der Kloot]: Therefore, in recognition of that, I'm saying, oh my gosh, you know, principal, I don't know what you're going to be able to do.

[Van der Kloot]: And I don't, I understand to me, it's not, this is one of the problems with a very tight timeline, I believe.

[Van der Kloot]: It's not giving a great opportunity for student input.

[Van der Kloot]: Please be advised on Wednesday, March 10th, from 4 to 5.30 PM, there will be a curriculum subcommittee meeting held through remote participation via Zoom.

[Van der Kloot]: The purpose of this meeting is to review the ELA language arts curriculum in the Medford Public Schools, pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law.

[Van der Kloot]: and the governor's March 15th order imposing strict limitations of the number of people who may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Van der Kloot]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website www.medfordmass.org.

[Van der Kloot]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Van der Kloot]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media websites an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record

[Van der Kloot]: of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: The meeting can be viewed through Medford Community Media on Comcast Channel 22 and Verizon Channel 43 at 4 p.m.

[Van der Kloot]: Medford Public Schools is inviting you to a scheduled Zoom meeting, mps02155-org-.zoom.us.

[Van der Kloot]: The number is 933-2658-3171, which is the meeting ID.

[Van der Kloot]: For a phone number, it's 1-301-7158-592.

[Van der Kloot]: Any questions or comments can be submitted during the meeting by emailing pvanderclude at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Van der Kloot]: Those submitting must include the following information, your first and last name, your Medford street address, and your question or comment.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, I mean, I certainly understand that as a parent who might have a, you know, second grader, they're counting and saying, oh, that's not gonna be made it, you know, for two years.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: as we look at rollouts for new curriculum.

[Van der Kloot]: The first was from Molly Leighton, director of our technology.

[Van der Kloot]: She spoke to the curriculum and what's covered in each of the grade levels.

[Van der Kloot]: She also spoke to questions like, what are her future goals?

[Van der Kloot]: She wants to expand the library makerspace, expansion of student tech help desks, bring girls who code club

[Van der Kloot]: Medford Public Schools and build course pathways.

[Van der Kloot]: Full-time librarians in all schools with certified school librarian tech integration leaders.

[Van der Kloot]: She did note that the department is light.

[Van der Kloot]: Part of that, of course, is due to the tragic death of a staff member.

[Van der Kloot]: One of the things that she also spoke of about was that computer skills, it's not just the computer classes, but also embedding skills within the curriculum across the board.

[Van der Kloot]: So it's not a standalone.

[Van der Kloot]: So example, writing on the computer, for example, using a slideshow to present a science project.

[Van der Kloot]: Tech teachers had to teach proficiently with keyboards for MCAS, use it throughout the day, and now extremely important that everyone has a Chromebook.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Layden said, I don't think so.

[Van der Kloot]: More a skill set than a set curriculum.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: We want our voices to be heard.

[Van der Kloot]: It is disturbing that such a monumental decision that changes the fabric of our city

[Van der Kloot]: was decided with a sheer lack of transparency and community input.

[Van der Kloot]: A decision of this magnitude should have been advertised far and wide across all media platforms and far in advance of a meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: It should not have been

[Van der Kloot]: advertised only to meet the letter of the law.

[Van der Kloot]: This is unconscionable.

[Van der Kloot]: We are deeply disappointed that any steps taken to move forward on this matter are considered ethnically biased, disrespectful, and thoughtless, insulting multiple generations of Italian-Americans who grew up, lived in, attended, and supported and contributed to the Columbus School as well as the city of Medford.

[Van der Kloot]: For Italian Americans, this school name has and will always be a source of pride and history.

[Van der Kloot]: This is a passionate and personal issue for many on.

[Van der Kloot]: on both sides and with other urgent matters much higher on the priority list that our city is facing, we are putting forth our best efforts to stop the Medford School Committee from changing the name of the Columbus School.

[Van der Kloot]: On Friday, March 5th, Educational Commissioner Riley ordered all elementary school students must return to in-person learning effective April 5th.

[Van der Kloot]: This should be the school committee's only priority at this time.

[Van der Kloot]: To quote a school committee member and their,

[Van der Kloot]: And there is a budget, quite possibly the most contentious budget ever, that we will be attempting to craft at the same time as replanning this year and planning next year.

[Van der Kloot]: It would be a gross abdication of responsibility to the children of Medford to spend time right now on the renaming of a school

[Van der Kloot]: when issues directly related to the well-being of our children are smack in front of them.

[Van der Kloot]: We request that our discussion regarding changing the name of the Columbus School be tabled at this time until our children have returned to school safely for the remainder of the academic year.

[Van der Kloot]: Budget issues are managed and there is a plan in place to return our children to the academic year 21-22.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you for your consideration, sincerely concerned citizens of Medford.

[Van der Kloot]: And then I have one more.

[Van der Kloot]: on this subject.

[Van der Kloot]: This was submitted by Brenna Christensen.

[Van der Kloot]: Dear Mayor Lungo-Koehn and members of the Medford School Committee, my name is Brenna Christensen and I am a graduate of the class of 2020 from Medford High School and a former captain of the varsity softball team.

[Van der Kloot]: I write to you today to request a name change to Columbus Memorial Park

[Van der Kloot]: the Crystal Campbell Field and to incorporate the name changing of the field to the future name change committee.

[Van der Kloot]: So she's recommending that we change the name of the Columbus School to the Crystal Campbell School.

[Van der Kloot]: Crystal Campbell was a Medford native, a victim of the Boston Marathon bombings.

[Van der Kloot]: She was an active member in our Mustang community and was in the band along with the softball team.

[Van der Kloot]: Crystal Campbell was known to light up any room she walked into and she loved sunflowers.

[Van der Kloot]: She is an inspiration to our city, our home, our residents, and our athletes.

[Van der Kloot]: Since 2013, the varsity softball team has held the Crystal Campbell Softball Tournament in mid-April at the Columbus Park Softball Field.

[Van der Kloot]: During the two-day tournament, us Mustangs competed against Boricua, Swampscott, and Arlington Catholic High School.

[Van der Kloot]: We actively fundraised during the tournament and throughout our season to donate to the Crystal Campbell Scholarship Fund.

[Van der Kloot]: On this day, our community comes together as one and united.

[Van der Kloot]: We are truly Medford strong.

[Van der Kloot]: Although this tournament may only be two days out of the year, during our entire season, we wear her name on our jersey.

[Van der Kloot]: And we wear it with immense pride.

[Van der Kloot]: It's a day when we give back to the community and honor Crystal's legacy.

[Van der Kloot]: Not only is the Columbus Park field home to our high school Mustang softball team, we share this field with our youth softball program and baseball as well.

[Van der Kloot]: We meet our forever friends, learn sportsmanship along with the importance of responsibility.

[Van der Kloot]: But for all of that, we make memories that will last a lifetime.

[Van der Kloot]: Each and every play on that field, we keep crystal close to our hearts and play in our honor.

[Van der Kloot]: I respectfully ask that we use our Medford strength, come together as one and rename our fields.

[Van der Kloot]: Let's continue the pride we feel when we wear Campbell on our jerseys and with a positive change to our city, the city we all love and with gratitude get to call home.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: Kind regards, Brenda Christensen, 80 Fern Road.

[Van der Kloot]: So excuse me, she may be asking just for the fields to carry the name and we would do that under a separate consideration, but we might forward her email to the advisory council anyway.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, can I just, there's a curriculum subcommittee meeting from 4 to 5.30.

[Van der Kloot]: I think originally people thought this meeting, our Committee of the Whole was going to be at 5.30, so just to repeat, it starts at 5.45.

[Van der Kloot]: Correct.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, so the one thing I just want to say is that the resolution that I'm sending to the Committee of the Whole talks about timeline as does Member Ruseau's.

[Van der Kloot]: This is quite separate from and different from discussing the key issue.

[Van der Kloot]: We've already made a decision that the school would be renamed.
