[Van der Kloot]: feelings about this and I certainly understand that there are people who are very angry about the process that was used right at the beginning.

[Van der Kloot]: In terms of the timing and us concentrating on what we need to, it was my intent after spending a great deal of time working out the potential for the advisory council to discuss the timeline

[Van der Kloot]: with the committee at that point.

[Van der Kloot]: To do so tonight without having reviewed the resolutions just simply won't make any sense.

[Van der Kloot]: It'll be random.

[Van der Kloot]: So while I appreciate hearing from my former colleague, the intent was to send the resolution to the subcommittee to discuss timelines and processes.

[Van der Kloot]: I referenced this earlier.

[Van der Kloot]: I very much in good faith went through the process of looking in detail with thanks to my colleague who I used his as a basis to work through all of the issues that I think the advisory council has.

[Van der Kloot]: Who's going to be on the advisory council?

[Van der Kloot]: What are they going to do?

[Van der Kloot]: How are they going to report it out?

[Van der Kloot]: Who's going to pick the names, et cetera?

[Van der Kloot]: Um,

[Van der Kloot]: My concern is having done that exercise is while in it, I kept the dates except for one week of that Paul had originally put in his, I don't think it's real.

[Van der Kloot]: I just don't think there's enough time to have a good reflective process, a thorough process for the advisory council.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm not saying that we should overturn our decision about Columbus, which I know many in the community would like.

[Van der Kloot]: For me, the most important thing is to try and figure a path forward, which brings us unity.

[Van der Kloot]: Earlier this evening, we heard those voices of our kids.

[Van der Kloot]: And as I was listening to the voices of our kids, I was thinking about this discussion that we were gonna have here.

[Van der Kloot]: which has been feeling such division.

[Van der Kloot]: And in our kids, we hear the hope and the desire for unity.

[Van der Kloot]: I think that the advisory council needs time to do its job well and not rushed.

[Van der Kloot]: As I've gotten older, I have more and more of appreciation for that word reflection.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, getting a chance to think about what we're doing and what name.

[Van der Kloot]: I have put in mind a chance for a public hearing, not to debate the issue of Columbus, but to look at the new names.

[Van der Kloot]: All along, I've been hopeful that we could come up with something that would honor our Italian heritage in this community, but also bring the community together.

[Van der Kloot]: We're not gonna do that fast.

[Van der Kloot]: It's not a slam dunk.

[Van der Kloot]: I know that there's much pain with the thought of even prolonging the process a minute longer.

[Van der Kloot]: I know that I don't really want it to go through this for month after month, but I am very, very concerned that in our short term, we do have a lot to do.

[Van der Kloot]: Sometimes tensions ran high.

[Van der Kloot]: And Charlene, I personally want to thank you for your leadership and for getting this done.

[Van der Kloot]: So thank you very much and to your team.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm all set mayor.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: So Melanie, Medford was one of the key districts.

[Van der Kloot]: There were either six, there's been one that went in and out and whatever, but was one of the original districts that started Shore Collaborative.

[Van der Kloot]: And so we had a very special relationship with them for a long time.

[Van der Kloot]: We also had far more students than our present enrollment.

[Van der Kloot]: And so the number of students has fallen as we've brought more kids back into our own programs, for example, and either sought different alternatives.

[Van der Kloot]: determined that they could provide better quality programs for a lot less expense.

[Van der Kloot]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn?

[Van der Kloot]: Absolutely.

[Van der Kloot]: So we had the building the future committee.

[Van der Kloot]: And I would say that it came somewhat similar in that there was a great deal of discussion amongst in the community about the shape.

[Van der Kloot]: And then several school committee members, including myself spearheaded, bringing it to the floor for discussion and, you know,

[Van der Kloot]: moving it forward.

[Van der Kloot]: One of the things which helped us was we had dynamic leadership of the committee.

[Van der Kloot]: Rick Orlando and Tricia McDonough really did such an incredibly fabulous job outlining the path.

[Van der Kloot]: The first discussions were, there was a series of events around the community, listening events, getting people's input.

[Van der Kloot]: What were they thinking?

[Van der Kloot]: What were they seeing?

[Van der Kloot]: What were their reactions?

[Van der Kloot]: and their concerns as we move forward.

[Van der Kloot]: And remember, at that point, there was no, you know, in a similar way, we had not preconceived that we were going to build four new schools.

[Van der Kloot]: We didn't know.

[Van der Kloot]: All of that came into being over the course of the process.

[Van der Kloot]: of the committee looking at the various different resources, concerns, land parcels availability, but even would they be K to H, would they be, none of that was preconceived.

[Van der Kloot]: That was all part of the work of the committee.

[Van der Kloot]: And that was then defined.

[Van der Kloot]: One of the things that was extremely important was there were different phases of the committee.

[Van der Kloot]: So the first was kind of the outreach

[Van der Kloot]: Then the second was taking the information and coming up with some decisions.

[Van der Kloot]: And those ones then were brought to the school committee for our input, because if we weren't buying it, there was no way we were going to be able to sell it to the community.

[Van der Kloot]: And then a variety of different meetings happened around

[Van der Kloot]: uh Medford uh you know outreaching to different groups and whatnot explaining what was um uh

[Van der Kloot]: what project proposals there were, what ideas there were, and narrowing it down.

[Van der Kloot]: So it's really quite a process in the same way that I think that we're thinking here.

[Van der Kloot]: Were there discussions about educational?

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, absolutely, and they need to be included as well.

[Van der Kloot]: One of the things though that is very interesting sort of looking back is that there will be people who say, I just don't understand why.

[Van der Kloot]: And they really have no understanding today why certain decisions were made back then about either the placement of the schools or why there's a K to eight and a middle school on one piece of property.

[Van der Kloot]: So that's one of the interesting things as time goes on, those pieces are lost to the community.

[Van der Kloot]: And then we have people saying, I don't understand this.

[Van der Kloot]: And I can tell you that all of those decisions were thoroughly vetted

[Van der Kloot]: and that there was a basis for each one of those decisions.

[Van der Kloot]: But over time, it does get lost.

[Van der Kloot]: And that's a valuable thing for me to realize as we go forward with this.

[Van der Kloot]: I do wanna mention, by the way, that there was at the time, the third stage of building the future committee, which is what we called it.

[Van der Kloot]: The third stage was the high school.

[Van der Kloot]: And there was some work

[Van der Kloot]: you know, things done over time.

[Van der Kloot]: And then at some point, Dr. Perrella, you may recall, the former headmaster of the high school, he put together a, he wanted to put together a grant and he looked very much at the library area and discussed a lot about what should be happening educationally in that area.

[Van der Kloot]: And I thought it was a very thorough vetting.

[Van der Kloot]: There was a, at the time,

[Van der Kloot]: There was a, they put together a presentation.

[Van der Kloot]: And that's something that you know as we're talking about the things we're talking about not just the physical structure but how is the building going to be used educationally, we should, even though of course I'm sure it needs to be updated but we should look back to that, what happened at that point to.

[Van der Kloot]: The, it was a very dedicated group of people.

[Van der Kloot]: They had to be able to meet.

[Van der Kloot]: I think at first we were meeting weekly.

[Van der Kloot]: We could check with Rick Orlando and Tricia about exactly that, but it was a long process.

[Van der Kloot]: I would say that it was probably about a year before we came

[Van der Kloot]: was the first presentation and the first narrowing down steps was, you know, it was a significant process of time.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't know if that answers the question.

[Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Van der Kloot]: We certainly had a few staff, but there were also people who acted.

[Van der Kloot]: They might have attended the meetings because they were giving information.

[Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Van der Kloot]: You know, so it depended, but I think we were we really started at ground zero without great

[Van der Kloot]: you know, with no preconceptions about what was going to happen.

[Van der Kloot]: One of the things I just wanted to mention was the importance of also having

[Van der Kloot]: members go out and even if just in the initial process we did visitations to other school districts and that was so important and that's really harder to do right now because of COVID but you know most of us are framed you know we know our high school maybe we've been in another one but we certainly you know haven't been in a lot and we we went to quite a few other districts and that was

[Van der Kloot]: very instrumental and that required that people were also available to take some time during the day.

[Van der Kloot]: And that was important because it excited us incredibly to see, to come out of our world and also to see what was being offered

[Van der Kloot]: in other districts.

[Van der Kloot]: And so I just want to mention that, that maybe it can be conveyed somewhat by people visiting and then doing presentations.

[Van der Kloot]: They can be, you know, that might be a job, if you would, that some people go, a smaller amount go and then make a presentation.

[Van der Kloot]: But that's just another aspect we want to make sure we're doing is visitations.

[Van der Kloot]: I want to ask member Rousseau to read what he had read at the beginning, his charge.

[Van der Kloot]: Paul, can you just repeat it?

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you, Paul, you know personally I think that's a fine starting point to be able to I mean, to take what Paul has has written and for us that to deliberate on it to give feedback to the superintendent and, and, you know, for us to

[Van der Kloot]: you know, then if she could develop some way to share that with us, and then I think that would make sense.

[Van der Kloot]: And while I can understand Jenny's concern about not Maurice having too much, I think it's absolutely critical that Maurice does play a strong role in this development.

[Van der Kloot]: So I think that works.

[Van der Kloot]: You know, I like Paul's starting point.

[Van der Kloot]: personally.

[Van der Kloot]: I think it's a good place to begin with, it's solid, but yet there's also a lot of potentials for discussion as well.

[Van der Kloot]: Today, the curriculum subcommittee meeting is called to order.

[Van der Kloot]: The purpose of this meeting is to review the math curriculum K to 12 in the Medford Public Schools.

[Van der Kloot]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, and the Governor's March 15 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Van der Kloot]: specific information and the general guidance for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and a requirement to attend this meeting can be found at the city of Medford website www.medfordmass.org.

[Van der Kloot]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[Van der Kloot]: No in-person attendance of meetings with the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[Van der Kloot]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford Community Media websites, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: after the meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: So the Medford, if you need to call in, the number is 312-626-6799.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: Lungo-Koehn?

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, so we met on November 18.

[Van der Kloot]: Present was myself, Jenny Graham.

[Van der Kloot]: Mia could not make it, so Paul Rousseau attended in her place.

[Van der Kloot]: We began with a presentation from Tanya Sullivan and Alex Lark, co-chairs of the Medford CPAC, and they made a presentation reminding us that they speak for 20% of Medford Public Schools students and

[Van der Kloot]: that they've been advocating for a disability awareness program for many years.

[Van der Kloot]: Also, Melanie McLaughlin also attended, and she was the previous head of the CPAC, and also was very active in this program.

[Van der Kloot]: advocating for this program.

[Van der Kloot]: Joan Bowen and Susanna Campbell presented the disability awareness in the classroom presentation.

[Van der Kloot]: Susanna Campbell is presented an overview of the course that she ran last year and is going to now run again this January.

[Van der Kloot]: The professional development is

[Van der Kloot]: available on the Professional Development website and is now open for registration.

[Van der Kloot]: It's open to all staff, not just teachers.

[Van der Kloot]: The program is going to run Thursday afternoons from 3.15 to 5.15 in January and February via Zoom.

[Van der Kloot]: The course includes the history of disabilities in the U.S.,

[Van der Kloot]: and U.S.

[Van der Kloot]: legislation, ableism, belief in our society that not being disabled is the norm, disability etiquette, so teachers can model disability etiquette, and asking a person what they want, if they want assistance rather than stepping in, and the unique needs of students with various disabilities, and also tools to break down stereotypes.

[Van der Kloot]: Key curricular concepts are positive representation of people with disabilities in content area lessons, universal design for learning helps all have better access, anti-ableism language practice into content area lessons, reframe misconceptions, building a more inclusive environment and creating a better community.

[Van der Kloot]: The next steps,

[Van der Kloot]: is to recruit is to have the PD course January and February of 2021 then recruit volunteers to pilot a disability awareness curriculum in February 2021 and then

[Van der Kloot]: a pilot in classrooms, March to May 2021.

[Van der Kloot]: This is not a one and done, and this is one of the most important things that really was stressed in the meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: This disability awareness, we want it to be embedded into everyday instruction, so that it's not something that which simply just happens once, it's a, you know, get some fanfare, and then it's left behind.

[Van der Kloot]: Rather, the concept

[Van der Kloot]: and the awareness needs to be embedded into the curriculum so it is ongoing.

[Van der Kloot]: That was a very important point.

[Van der Kloot]: We talked about a book that one fifth grade teacher was using and the lesson plans that had come out of that.

[Van der Kloot]: Last time, 48 teachers took the course and it's hoping that there will be as many this time.

[Van der Kloot]: It's done on a volunteer basis.

[Van der Kloot]: And the end result is creating curriculum units that can be shared amongst our staff.

[Van der Kloot]: Again, we talked a little bit about why we weren't doing a specialized curriculum, but rather embedding it in.

[Van der Kloot]: CPAC had done research on this in past years and there had been an attempt at the one school, but it ended up being a special event rather than having the long-term impact.

[Van der Kloot]: Let's see.

[Van der Kloot]: We're starting from the pilot and we're growing from there.

[Van der Kloot]: And

[Van der Kloot]: Susanna Campbell mentioned that we're taking a two-pronged course.

[Van der Kloot]: One is about teaching students.

[Van der Kloot]: The other part is teaching teachers to use universal design to help them become more knowledgeable about disabilities.

[Van der Kloot]: We've asked that there would be a report and update at the end of the year, and that's been scheduled.

[Van der Kloot]: And so we'll be reporting back to the committee about how many teachers signed up and took the course and how many volunteers we had and how we were able to implement this this year, this year being 2021 in the spring.

[Van der Kloot]: Lastly, I just want to mention to you that the

[Van der Kloot]: The next meeting is on December 10th, but that is this Thursday.

[Van der Kloot]: And we're going to be looking at the math curriculum.

[Van der Kloot]: We also wanted to convey our thanks both to the, particularly to Tanya Sullivan and Alex Lorick of the CPAC and to Susanna Campbell and Joan Bowen for all the work they did in giving the information for us for this subcommittee.

[Van der Kloot]: That's it.

[Van der Kloot]: Is that correct?

[Van der Kloot]: it's very unsettling.

[Van der Kloot]: I mean, I certainly understand that that is an important piece of what our staff and teachers are conveying to us is that they're nervous about it.

[Van der Kloot]: But what you're saying right now is there's really been no change in the data, which would suggest that we need to do something different in terms of having students come to school.

[Van der Kloot]: Is that correct?

[Van der Kloot]: I guess then the next question really goes to the superintendent.

[Van der Kloot]: When we see the number of staff getting higher because they're on quarantine, do we have enough?

[Van der Kloot]: And I know that there's been an incredible effort

[Van der Kloot]: to cover classes and that the administrative people and others have just really stepped up and covered.

[Van der Kloot]: My recollection from all other times is what we do is that each of us individually will fill out an evaluation once the superintendent gives us her self evaluation and then we'll gather as a committee and discuss it and

[Van der Kloot]: decide how we're gonna come up with either a collaborative document to then share with the superintendent.

[Van der Kloot]: by mid-January at the latest, so that we can go ahead with the process.

[Van der Kloot]: And I think we're all in agreement, really.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes, I think we've already articulated many goals which we could write down and then we could take a look at and articulate goals for the rest of the year.

[Van der Kloot]: So that means that if the superintendent gives us her self-evaluation at the first

[Van der Kloot]: or even the second meeting in January, and the first might be preferable, or mid-Feb, whatever, that we will have set up a committee of the whole meeting, and we will commit to having done the self-evaluations and the other steps.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm saying that because I think Jenny does have a point that we want to get it done.

[Van der Kloot]: So that's why I'm putting an end date.

[Van der Kloot]: If we get it done before that, that's even better.

[Van der Kloot]: But this way, we've given the superintendent enough time, but we've committed ourselves to making sure it gets done.

[Van der Kloot]: I understand your

[Van der Kloot]: your need to make sure that it's started early and that process is started early.

[Van der Kloot]: But again, I just personally, I think that we need to trust the superintendent.

[Van der Kloot]: And if she's not setting up the budget in a timely fashion or whatever, and I just don't think we have to legislate it as my own personal opinion.

[Van der Kloot]: I think that if you're,

[Van der Kloot]: Concerned about it or any member is concerned about it.

[Van der Kloot]: I think that for me that the best way about it is having conversation with the superintendent and only if she's not then being responsive would you then go about and put it in a resolution.

[Van der Kloot]: So my personal opinion is that this falls under the superintendent's purview and you're suggesting I think that you would like to have it sooner rather than later.

[Van der Kloot]: If you want to go forward with your resolution, which I'm sure you do, I would just suggest that we say that by the end of January, just to give her a little more latitude.

[Van der Kloot]: So I would amend it to be the end of January.

[Van der Kloot]: Will you accept the amendment to the end of January, Jenny?

[Van der Kloot]: So I think I've offered an amendment.

[Van der Kloot]: I think Kathy has seconded it.

[Van der Kloot]: of the travel for our students, travel for our teachers, the conditions.

[Van der Kloot]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th order submitting certain provisions of the open meeting law,

[Van der Kloot]: 301 paragraph 18 in the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[Van der Kloot]: This meeting of the Medford School Committee will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[Van der Kloot]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordmass.org.

[Van der Kloot]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn.

[Van der Kloot]: There we go.

[Van der Kloot]: So the curriculum subcommittee met on Wednesday, February 26, between 4.30 and 5.30 at the superintendent's conference room in Medford High School.

[Van der Kloot]: In attendance were the subcommittee members, myself and Jenny Graham.

[Van der Kloot]: Mia was absent.

[Van der Kloot]: School committee member Paul Rousseau

[Van der Kloot]: attended the meeting, as did Superintendent Maryse Edward-Vincent, Associate Superintendent Diane Caldwell, Assistant Superintendent Peter Cushing, Director of Curriculum and Instruction Bernadette Riccidelli, Director of PE Health Rachel Puri, and Middle School Parent Michelle Ciccolo.

[Van der Kloot]: I called the meeting together at 435 and we saluted the flag.

[Van der Kloot]: The purpose of the meeting was to review proposed additions to the middle school health curriculum.

[Van der Kloot]: We received handouts from Rachel Puri, including the table of contents for the national health standards and a table reviewing the current Medford health curriculum with the national standards.

[Van der Kloot]: Areas where we were not in alignment were highlighted.

[Van der Kloot]: Director Puri reviewed the charts with the subcommittee.

[Van der Kloot]: Currently we use part of the Michigan model, but now we should be incorporating more areas of the most recent Michigan model edition to cover areas related to sexual health.

[Van der Kloot]: We are covering areas such as vaping, alcohol, drug education, nutrition, physical activity, safety, and other areas of social emotional learning.

[Van der Kloot]: Currently, the state standards are not out.

[Van der Kloot]: So at present, we need to rely on the national standards.

[Van der Kloot]: Director Perry explained the health is offered for a half year in grade six, seventh, and eighth.

[Van der Kloot]: The other half of the year, the students receive instruction from guidance in order to cover the new areas of instruction.

[Van der Kloot]: In order to cover the new areas of instruction, one full-time health teacher will be needed.

[Van der Kloot]: Member Graham asked about the trade-off between students receiving health versus the ability to participate in band or orchestra.

[Van der Kloot]: Parent Ciccolo noted that her child had no health in sixth grade because of a conflict with orchestra,

[Van der Kloot]: In seventh grade, her child traded phys ed in order to get health instruction.

[Van der Kloot]: School committee member Rousseau noted that often students on IEPs miss subjects like health.

[Van der Kloot]: Assistant Superintendent Peter Cushing said that our kids are under a constant bombardment on vaping and other risky behaviors.

[Van der Kloot]: He believes a trained health professional is of highest priority, a must have.

[Van der Kloot]: Guiding staff not trained to teach these health areas.

[Van der Kloot]: The superintendent concurred and noted that budget decisions are going to be tough because of the many needs.

[Van der Kloot]: Since the new curriculum covers areas related to sex education, such as gender identity, anatomy, puberty, and contraception, all parents will receive the opt-out notification, which the district has used for many years.

[Van der Kloot]: The sequencing of the curriculum will be given careful consideration.

[Van der Kloot]: The high school ninth grade health class will be reviewed and updated.

[Van der Kloot]: Scheduling at the middle school is challenging.

[Van der Kloot]: Member Graham offered the following statement to summarize our current position.

[Van der Kloot]: We recognize that there are scheduling issues that mean parents have to make choices that we would rather they did not have to make.

[Van der Kloot]: We are very aware of the issues and are working to address them.

[Van der Kloot]: Motion by Member Graham, seconded by myself.

[Van der Kloot]: The Curriculum Subcommittee recommends that the school committee adopt Growing Up and Staying Healthy Michigan model health curriculum with supplements in order to assure that we are aligned with the national health standards.

[Van der Kloot]: Roll call was Graham, yes.

[Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot, yes.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Stone was absent.

[Van der Kloot]: Motion to adjourn at 5.30 by Member Graham and seconded by myself.

[Van der Kloot]: And the motion passed.

[Van der Kloot]: So we would like to make a motion tonight.

[Van der Kloot]: We would ask that the school committee adopt, recommendation is that we adopt growing up, the subcommittee recommendation is that we adopt growing up and staying healthy, the Michigan model health curriculum with supplements.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't know.

[Van der Kloot]: I think there were resources that the teachers would be using.

[Van der Kloot]: They were not specified.

[Van der Kloot]: However, we did address the needs of the fact that there was concerns about getting the curriculum to everybody.

[Van der Kloot]: And that's one of the reasons why the recommendation is to add a full-time health

[Van der Kloot]: teacher at that level, because we need to be more comprehensive in our ability to deliver the information to students, all students.

[Van der Kloot]: Am I correct in saying when it's tabled, it's tabled?

[Van der Kloot]: OK.

[Van der Kloot]: Member Graham.

[Van der Kloot]: »» Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: Can I make a clarification?

[Van der Kloot]: »» Sure.

[Van der Kloot]: »» The reason I motioned to table it was because a member asked for additional information that I did not provide.

[Van der Kloot]: Because typically when we've had a handout we don't always provide it that's not customary.

[Van der Kloot]: But I didn't provide it and since a member asked for that information and we didn't provide it, that's why I made the motion to lay it on the table.

[Van der Kloot]: Well, if I may, there's also a budget piece of getting a, whether we're going to approve the additional health personnel, which is going to make this possible.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, I absolutely understand.

[Van der Kloot]: I think that as soon as a member requests a piece of information, I mean, the mayor just said, I don't feel comfortable voting on it unless I see that.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, so, uh, it would be as you and I both being on the subcommittee, we very, very much want to see this go through.

[Van der Kloot]: Um,

[Van der Kloot]: At this point, I'm willing to wait for two weeks.

[Van der Kloot]: I would not have to read the minutes again.

[Van der Kloot]: We would just have to bring it back up.

[Van der Kloot]: So I'll lay it on the table to the next meeting.

[Van der Kloot]: Member Ruseau?

[Van der Kloot]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn.

[Van der Kloot]: I'd like to ask for suspension of, oh, sorry, not yet.

[Van der Kloot]: Hold on.

[Van der Kloot]: Member van der Kloot.

[Van der Kloot]: I had a question about the timeline.

[Van der Kloot]: I also, I guess my first question is, did the subcommittee endorse, I don't see a motion for approval.

[Van der Kloot]: Was there, sorry, where is it?

[Van der Kloot]: And was it a three to one vote?

[Van der Kloot]: Or a three to zero vote?

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: So I have a question about, okay, here, I see it now.

[Van der Kloot]: I have a question about the timeline.

[Van der Kloot]: It appears that it gives the superintendent or her designee within two normal school days to respond with the following.

[Van der Kloot]: You know, when I'm up there signing the bills on Wednesday, I have to say that my observation is that people are running, running, running, juggling so many balls in the air.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't think two normal school days is sufficient.

[Van der Kloot]: I understand everybody thinks that whatever they have, as do I, is the most pressing issue.

[Van der Kloot]: But I don't think that's real to hold the superintendent to, and I don't want her to be under pressure to simply

[Van der Kloot]: designating something to everybody else.

[Van der Kloot]: And then sometimes she may need to think about it.

[Van der Kloot]: So I don't find two days to be sufficient.

[Van der Kloot]: I would ask the superintendent, since this affects you directly, is what sort of timeline you would think would be reasonable?

[Van der Kloot]: Member van de Kloot.

[Van der Kloot]: Sure, so first I want to say I do appreciate the work that the subcommittee did on this.

[Van der Kloot]: The superintendent has indicated her willingness to try it out.

[Van der Kloot]: My concern, again, just stands, perhaps I would change it to three normal school days.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm trying to work through my head.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, it's written on Sunday, it gets sent so it's received Monday.

[Van der Kloot]: That means the expectation is that it would get answered by Tuesday.

[Van der Kloot]: afternoon, but all hell breaks out loose on Monday and Tuesday they're running about.

[Van der Kloot]: So, you know, again, part of me just, I absolutely understand, you know, what the intent is and I think we are all reasonable people, but I'm always concerned when we write policy like this that someone then could come along and be holding, hold the superintendent to something that we agreed would be flexible and we're trying out.

[Van der Kloot]: And so, to me, it just seems very quick.

[Van der Kloot]: And I'd be more comfortable with a three-day return, personally.

[Van der Kloot]: I would go, certainly, with asking the rest of the school committee whether, you know, I'll make a motion that the response within three normal school days as opposed to two, and you either vote up or down, and I'm happy to take whatever the consensus is.

[Van der Kloot]: So I make a motion, if anybody wants to

[Van der Kloot]: you know, approve it or second it, that'd be three.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, thank you, Kathy.

[Van der Kloot]: the new teacher be monitored carefully just to make sure that he or she is doing whatever they're supposed to be doing.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: A couple of things.

[Van der Kloot]: I think, just as a comment, I think that my initial reading of this was I was almost a little disappointed, and people have touched on this, that we weren't doing the DIBLS 8 at one of our schools.

[Van der Kloot]: Because just from a kind of common sense place of where we're sitting is, oh, that means that we're testing different assessment tools.

[Van der Kloot]: and getting an idea of how they work.

[Van der Kloot]: So, but that's, you know, it's kind of almost a common sense that my initial reaction was saying, oh wait, they're not doing DIBLS-8?

[Van der Kloot]: Well, I thought we should be because we should be looking at all of them.

[Van der Kloot]: The next thing is we were passing around the colored

[Van der Kloot]: places, pieces.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, so I wanted to know what you do for a child who's colorblind.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: And a student who's coming in who has been speaking a different language?

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay, great.

[Van der Kloot]: And my last comment really is, and this really comes from speaking to my own daughter recently, recently, and the whole question of dyslexic, and she is dyslexic and was not identified until really till older in high school.

[Van der Kloot]: But she said to me, well, mom, of course we should have known because I was always in the low reading group.

[Van der Kloot]: and made clear the pain of being stigmatized in the low reading group.

[Van der Kloot]: And here we're talking a lot about taking students and determining what they know can do and not, but it also opens up and raises the concern of saying that those kids then are grouped together as the poor readers.

[Van der Kloot]: And I just, I don't know how we're doing that today, but Nicole.

[Van der Kloot]: Just one last, because you brought it up.

[Van der Kloot]: So one of the interesting things about my daughter, she can read on a computer screen much, much easier than she can read on a page.

[Van der Kloot]: So how do we differentiate when we're giving a computer test for those kids for her who might struggle with the written page?

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: The increase, say, between the last year and this new year one, do you know what that is approximately?

[Van der Kloot]: It's roughly 4%.

[Van der Kloot]: Okay.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: To my colleague, it would make more sense for you to make the motion that prior to the next implementation or prior to the next time contract that we do a study.

[Van der Kloot]: So if I could ask you to reword it.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: Van der Kloot.

[Van der Kloot]: The other thing I just want to remind my colleague is that, while I understand that it sounds great to say, well, we want to give Medford people jobs, this company may be employing Medford people.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't know who the employees are.

[Van der Kloot]: I do know that there were multiple employees who have already worked for the company.

[Van der Kloot]: And so to just, you know,

[Van der Kloot]: While it may sound great, that statement may sound great, I think it's superficial because the fact of the matter is that there are probably people, I know that we have gotten good feedback on the employees, and I'd hate to just put them out of work because we had some other thought of, oh, Medford people.

[Van der Kloot]: Well, maybe they are Medford people.

[Van der Kloot]: It's a little more complex than that.

[Van der Kloot]: There is a motion for approval.

[Van der Kloot]: As I said to Joseph coming in, it's such an honor

[Van der Kloot]: to know him.

[Van der Kloot]: And it was.

[Van der Kloot]: It's nothing new.

[Van der Kloot]: We're so excited over the years watching you grow and your family.

[Van der Kloot]: It's been so great.

[Van der Kloot]: And, you know, this is one of those moments, I think, that when I live a very long and healthy life, I'm going to say, I knew him when.

[Van der Kloot]: And it's just great.

[Van der Kloot]: So thank you so much, Joseph.

[Van der Kloot]: Thank you.

[Van der Kloot]: So I thought about this a lot, and because I was disappointed that students who really would have liked to have gone to the March

[Van der Kloot]: didn't go because they would have adversely affected their team because they're not allowed to take part in those activities.

[Van der Kloot]: But to me, while there was a question of timing, it happened quickly.

[Van der Kloot]: We only knew about it, or I only knew about it the day before.

[Van der Kloot]: To me, this is a school committee policy question.

[Van der Kloot]: And to me, I feel like the administrative people probably are doing their job.

[Van der Kloot]: And now I have to step in and say, this is a policy question.

[Van der Kloot]: I think we need to look at the policy.

[Van der Kloot]: I don't think that students should be penalized for attending a climate change march.

[Van der Kloot]: I'd love it to be an educational opportunity.

[Van der Kloot]: I would even consider some sort of, I mean, I agree with Paul that that distinction between excused and unexcused, perhaps we need to talk about that overall because I've had parents come to me

[Van der Kloot]: with frustration about that policy in the bigger sense.

[Van der Kloot]: Because they say, you know, my kid was sick, but not so sick that they needed to go to the doctor.

[Van der Kloot]: So I just put aside over to the left and say, we have a bigger question.

[Van der Kloot]: But I do believe it's a policy.

[Van der Kloot]: So I'd like to make a motion that the school committee meet to discuss the absentee policy, especially in regards to outside events.

[Van der Kloot]: that students would like to participate in.

[Van der Kloot]: I think that if we can sit down around the table and come to a better way to handle this, that this would be better for our students, and then we wouldn't be putting our administrators, you know, holding them up with annoyance.

[Van der Kloot]: So, if I could.

[Van der Kloot]: I just want to be clear that by asking to send this to the policy committee, it's not because in any way that I agree with it.

[Van der Kloot]: I didn't agree with the choice.

[Van der Kloot]: It's just because I'm taking the power that we have as school committee members, and that is to make and set policy.

[Van der Kloot]: And I think that's the way that we can go about it and craft what we

[Van der Kloot]: will agree on.

[Van der Kloot]: I also just want to mention in all of this, the one thing that I kept on thinking about was that lovely young lady that came to us last spring, wanting to bring to our attention her frustration with the styrofoam trays.

[Van der Kloot]: And I think now it's September, and I know we're working on it, but yet it doesn't feel like

[Van der Kloot]: we're really concerned enough, because if we're concerned enough, then price wouldn't be a matter, and we would get reusable trays.

[Van der Kloot]: I was at Tufts yesterday, at the Tufts Community Day, and I noticed all the plates were, they're recycled paper.

[Van der Kloot]: And so I'm concerned that our own body isn't feeling the pressure enough, that we're gonna get to it,

[Van der Kloot]: but we're not getting to it fast enough.

[Van der Kloot]: And I think that it's up to us when we have a student like this, and we all agreed, we all agreed what we should do, that we should make it happen, not wait until it happens.

[Van der Kloot]: It may be trickier than you think because the excused and unexcused, I mean, I'm not sure that matters as much as, and I don't think we can go back and unfortunately change the fact that the real issue was they couldn't participate in their extracurriculars if they went.

[Van der Kloot]: And that's what is at the real meat of this, is that that's what the problem was.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm not certain.

[Van der Kloot]: So just as I try to think about this and I may need some help from the administration here of saying we could ask students if they went to the climate change on Friday, I guess that's how we would identify who went as opposed to who was sick or who was whatever.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm not quite sure.

[Van der Kloot]: I think we kind of need to look at our policy.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm not against it, Michael.

[Van der Kloot]: I'm just not quite sure how to do it.

[Van der Kloot]: We could, it doesn't have to be decided tonight, we could go to that policy, the policy subcommittee and we could discuss it there and it could be retroactive.

[Van der Kloot]: Would that be okay?

[Van der Kloot]: Well, I commend Kathy for volunteering to be the chair, and she may very well end up.

[Van der Kloot]: Just as we did with the superintendent search,

[Van der Kloot]: We asked the community who was interested in it.

[Van der Kloot]: It was a hot day, but very, very nice.

[Van der Kloot]: And I just wanted to ask you about the grade implementation, because on one it says K to 2.

[Van der Kloot]: So, I would think that it seems to me that there is a leap of faith here, to some extent, by going with this.

[Van der Kloot]: Because we have the statistics between two of our schools, and someone answered about a bus being late.

[Van der Kloot]: Well, I'm sure hoping that the principal who's meeting that bus that is late is the caring individual who we know that they are and who will usher that it's not a, you know, all of a sudden breakfast is going to close and the door is closed and there's no chance.

[Van der Kloot]: When I was a guidance Councilor over in Everett, there was a child who consistently came late to school and we knew had no food.

[Van der Kloot]: And I want to tell you, we always managed to get that child food by going down to the kitchen, by getting help, and we had no breakfast program at that time set up for that.

[Van der Kloot]: And present at the meeting were Mayor Burke, Vice Chair Anne Marie Cugno, Arenda Benedetto, Kathy Kreatz, Mia Mustone, Robert Scurry, and myself.

[Van der Kloot]: Also attending was Michael Ruggiero and Paul Rousseau, school committee members left.

[Van der Kloot]: Also present were the following Deputy Superintendent Beverly Nelson, Assistant Superintendent Diane Caldwell, Director of Pupil Services Kathleen Medaglio, Director of Curriculum Bernadette Scurry.

[Van der Kloot]: uh, Director of Finance and Administration, Kirsteen Patterson, Director of Foreign Language, Rita DeCarlo, Supervisor of Health Services, Tony Vento, Assistant Athletic Director, Rachel Perry, um, Headmaster, John Perrella, Principal, Paul DeLeva, Principal, Jacob Edwards, Assistant Principal, Nick Tucci, Athletic Trainer, Tanya Cashman, Tim Zitt, Registrar, Curtis Tootin, and other community members, including Tammy Simenotis,

[Van der Kloot]: uh, Marie Petrides, Angela Moore, David Lu, Melanie McLaughlin, Tanya Sullivan, and Jameel Webb Davis.

[Van der Kloot]: Transcript recorder Miranda Wilson was also in attendance.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, the mayor, uh, the, the meeting was called, uh, to discuss school brains, the field trip policy, follow up on student concussions, and report on the North Medford bus.

[Van der Kloot]: It was a very substantial meeting, went on for hours.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, I just added that Superintendent Johnson made the following remarks the evenings.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, and by the way, sorry, it was there was a there was mistake.

[Van der Kloot]: It should be Bernadette Riccadeli.

[Van der Kloot]: Uh, so we addressed the four different issues.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, and the first item was the report of the North Medford bus capacity and ridership, uh, director of administration and finance Christine Patterson gave the

[Van der Kloot]: report and it's attached.

[Van der Kloot]: And Principal Tucci verified the report.

[Van der Kloot]: There are two buses coming from North Medford in the morning and in the afternoon there are between 45 to 50 riders daily which is within its capacity.

[Van der Kloot]: At this time there's no need to add another bus.

[Van der Kloot]: administration will keep the committee informed as demand increases.

[Van der Kloot]: The next item was student concussions.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, we talked about this at length.

[Van der Kloot]: Um, as part of our discussions, parent Tammy Simonotis spoke of her son's experience at Beverly High School.

[Van der Kloot]: She asserted that her son was injured during a JV soccer game and that there was inadequate trainer medical coverage by the Beverly staff.

[Van der Kloot]: She believes that the Beverly schools did not have a certified trainer at the game.

[Van der Kloot]: Her son suffered a head injury, chipped teeth and nosebleeds.

[Van der Kloot]: The concern focused upon safety at away games.

[Van der Kloot]: Members of our staff spoke with the athletic director at Beverly, but really haven't received any more news.

[Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Simone was pleased with how Medford handles injuries, but was very upset at the Beverly response.

[Van der Kloot]: Concern was particularly high because the game was allowed to go on after the injury took place.

[Van der Kloot]: The superintendent promised that he will be conferring with the MIA regarding this matter.

[Van der Kloot]: The next item under discussion was the field trip policy and administrators Paul Deliva, Tony Vento and Kathy Medaglio contributed comments during the discussions.

[Van der Kloot]: CPAC chairperson Melanie McLaughlin raised equity issues about the policy and commented that CPAC should have been consulted as the policy was formulated.

[Van der Kloot]: There was a discussion about the annual trip to New York by the Andrew School and the questions about deadlines.

[Van der Kloot]: Among the 90 students who attended, there were 19 students who either had an IEP or 504 plan, and this was 19% of the participants.

[Van der Kloot]: If we had added another bus, it would have cost approximately $7,500 and would not have made the trip doable.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: McLaughlin asserted that the trip excluded students with disabilities and that every trip should be planned to serve all interested students.

[Van der Kloot]: The issue raised several points.

[Van der Kloot]: Can field trips be planned with application deadlines if those deadlines are applicable to all students?

[Van der Kloot]: Should field trips be limited if the economics cannot be balanced?

[Van der Kloot]: And should the cost of medical services be shared by all participants or subsidized by the school system?

[Van der Kloot]: After continued discussion, the policy was tabled.

[Van der Kloot]: Administrators will bring forward a revised policy that addresses the issues.

[Van der Kloot]: The final issue of the evening was school brains.

[Van der Kloot]: Headmaster Perella and Data Information Specialist Registrar Curtis Tudin gave us a report.

[Van der Kloot]: The headmaster reported that changes had been made to address the GPA concerns raised during the spring by Mr. David Lu.

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Tudin provided a chart that showed the increase in usage by parents and teachers.

[Van der Kloot]: More will be done going forward.

[Van der Kloot]: This is a work in progress, but it is moving forward.

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Liu was still skeptical about the accuracy of the reporting system.

[Van der Kloot]: He revisited his concerns from last spring.

[Van der Kloot]: Administrators asserted that the changes would work.

[Van der Kloot]: The school committee asked to be informed as the year progressed.

[Van der Kloot]: The meeting was adjourned at ten oh five respectfully submitted Paulette Van der Kloot secretary.

[Van der Kloot]: So we addressed the four different issues.

[Van der Kloot]: And the first item was the report of the North Medford bus capacity and ridership.

[Van der Kloot]: Director of administration and finance, Christine Patterson, gave this report, and it's attached.

[Van der Kloot]: uh, Tucci verified the report.

[Van der Kloot]: There are two buses coming from North Medford in the morning, um, and in the afternoon there are between 45 to 50 riders daily with each, which is within its capacity.

[Van der Kloot]: At this time there's no need to add another bus.

[Van der Kloot]: Administration will

[Van der Kloot]: Keep the committee informed as demand increases.

[Van der Kloot]: The next item was student concussions.

[Van der Kloot]: We talked about this at length.

[Van der Kloot]: As part of our discussions, parent Tammy Simonotis spoke of her son's experience at Beverly High School.

[Van der Kloot]: She asserted that her son was injured during a JV soccer game and that there was inadequate trainer medical coverage by the Beverly staff.

[Van der Kloot]: She believes that the Beverly Schools did not have a certified trainer at the game.

[Van der Kloot]: Her son suffered a head injury, chipped teeth, and nosebleeds.

[Van der Kloot]: Her concern focused upon safety at away games.

[Van der Kloot]: Members of our staff spoke with the athletic director at Beverly, but really haven't received any more news.

[Van der Kloot]: Mrs. Simone was pleased with how Medford handles injuries, but was very upset at the Beverly response.

[Van der Kloot]: Concern was particularly high because the game was allowed to go on after the injury took place.

[Van der Kloot]: The superintendent promised that he will be conferring with the MIAA regarding this matter.

[Van der Kloot]: The next item under discussion was the field trip policy and administrators Paul DeLiva, Tony Vento, and Kathy Medaglio contributed comments during the discussions.

[Van der Kloot]: CPAC chairperson Melanie McLaughlin raised equity issues about the policy and commented that CPAC should have been consulted as the policy was formulated.

[Van der Kloot]: There was a discussion about the annual trip to New York by the Andrew School and the questions about deadlines.

[Van der Kloot]: Among the 90 students who attended, there were 19 students who either had an IEP or 504 plan, and this was 19% of the participants.

[Van der Kloot]: If we had added another bus, it would have cost approximately $7,500 and would not have made the trip doable.

[Van der Kloot]: Ms.

[Van der Kloot]: McLaughlin asserted that the trip excluded students with disabilities and that every trip should be planned to serve all interested students.

[Van der Kloot]: The issue raised several points.

[Van der Kloot]: Can field trips be planned with application deadlines if those deadlines are applicable to all students?

[Van der Kloot]: Should field trips be limited if the economics cannot be balanced?

[Van der Kloot]: And should the cost of medical services be shared by all participants or subsidized by the school system?

[Van der Kloot]: After continued discussion, the policy was tabled.

[Van der Kloot]: Administrators will bring forward a revised policy that addresses the issues.

[Van der Kloot]: The final issue of the evening was school brains.

[Van der Kloot]: Headmaster Perrella and Data Information Specialist Registrar Curtis Tudin gave us a report.

[Van der Kloot]: The headmaster reported that changes had been made to address the GPA concerns raised during the spring by Mr. David Lu.

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Tudin provided a chart that showed the increase in usage by parents and teachers.

[Van der Kloot]: More will be done going forward.

[Van der Kloot]: This is a work in progress, but it is moving forward.

[Van der Kloot]: Mr. Liu was still skeptical about the accuracy of the reporting system.

[Van der Kloot]: He revisited his concerns from last spring.

[Van der Kloot]: Administrators asserted that the changes would work.

[Van der Kloot]: The school committee asked to be informed as the year progressed.

[Van der Kloot]: The meeting was adjourned at 10.05.

[Van der Kloot]: Respectfully submitted, Paulette Van der Kloot, secretary.

[Van der Kloot]: But we do have the student who this happened to.

[Van der Kloot]: Right.

[Van der Kloot]: And we could have a follow-up with the student.

[Van der Kloot]: I noticed that the Tufts Alternative School has a very low participation.

[Van der Kloot]: Yes.

[Van der Kloot]: And this really surprised me because I would think it would almost be the natural environment where kids would be coming in and might pick up some breakfast at school.

[Van der Kloot]: Do you have any insight into that number?

[Van der Kloot]: And the other thing I noticed is most of the schools, we see an increase between September and October.

[Van der Kloot]: There was only one school where there was a slight decline.

[Van der Kloot]: And I just want to make sure that we keep on looking at these numbers because I wouldn't want there to be any stigma attached to kids going in for breakfast.

[Van der Kloot]: That's why I think the classroom environment really is ideal.

[Van der Kloot]: Nice.
